question_text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because he does not “listen to her” anymore. She reports that since he started preschool 10 months ago, he has not been able to concentrate on any tasks lasting longer than a few minutes. His preschool teachers report he is more active compared to other preschoolers, frequently interrupts or bothers other children, and is very forgetful. He was born at term via vaginal delivery and has been healthy except for 3 episodes of acute otitis media at the age of 2 years. He has met all developmental milestones. His mother has major depressive disorder and his father has Graves disease. He appears healthy and well nourished. On examination, the patient turns his head briefly toward the examiner and sometimes makes eye contact when spoken to but does not respond to direct questions and continues to play with and touch objects in the physician's office. He interrupts his mother and the physician frequently during the examination to express his wish to go outside and eat a snack. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because he does not “listen to her” anymore. She reports that since he started preschool 10 months ago, he has not been able to concentrate on any tasks lasting longer than a few minutes. His preschool teachers report he is more active compared to other preschoolers, frequently interrupts or bothers other children, and is very forgetful. He was born at term via vaginal delivery and has been healthy except for 3 episodes of acute otitis media at the age of 2 years. He has met all developmental milestones. His mother has major depressive disorder and his father has Graves disease. He appears healthy and well nourished. On examination, the patient turns his head briefly toward the examiner and sometimes makes eye contact when spoken to but does not respond to direct questions and continues to play with and touch objects in the physician's office. He interrupts his mother and the physician frequently during the examination to express his wish to go outside and eat a snack. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with impulsivity, hyperactivity, and inattention in two settings (at school and at home) for more than 6 months, which is consistent with the diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).
learning_objective: Recognize ADHD in preschool-aged children, and choose the initial management strategy.

answers.explanation_why: Behavioral interventions, including behavioral therapy and socio-educational measures (e.g., creation of a low-stimulus environment, providing support for learning disabilities), are considered the first-line treatment for ADHD in preschool-aged children (4–5 years of age). Behavioral therapy is most successful when guided by parents or guardians; for this reason, behavioral parent training is recommended for all parents of children with ADHD. Pharmacotherapy (preferably with stimulants such as methylphenidate) is only recommended in patients who are ≥ 6 years of age.

Fluoxetine therapy is indicated in the treatment of major depressive disorder (MDD) and disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD). MDD can present with irritability, psychomotor agitation, and inability to concentrate, as seen in this patient. However, to diagnose MDD, ≥ 5 out of 9 typical symptoms, including anhedonia or depressed/irritable mood, have to be present over a 2-week period, which is not the case in this patient. As for DMDD, extreme irritability, anger, and severe recurrent angry outbursts (verbal or behavioral) in more than one setting are the findings required for diagnosis. Although this patient has been aggressive towards his teachers and classmates, he does not meet the criteria for this condition.

The use of hearing aids is indicated in children with conductive hearing loss. This boy's history of multiple episodes of acute otitis media should raise concern for hearing loss. However, the patient makes eye contact when spoken to. He also uses clear language and has reached all developmental milestones, which would be unlikely if hearing loss had been present from the age of 2. Hearing aids are not the best initial treatment for this patient.

Atomoxetine is considered the second-line treatment for ADHD in children ≥ 6 years of age, adolescents, and adults. However, it is preferred over stimulants (because of their addictive potential) in patients with a personal or family history of substance abuse and in patients with parents or guardians who object to the use of stimulants. Since this patient does not meet these criteria, atomoxetine would not be indicated. Furthermore, atomoxetine is also rarely used in patients < 6 years of age.

Stimulants such as methylphenidate are the first-line therapy for school-aged children (≥ 6 years of age) and adolescents with ADHD. Stimulants have a rapid onset of action and are very effective at increasing cognitive performance (e.g., improved concentration, cognition, short-term memory, and fine motor skills) and reducing impulsiveness and aggression. However, in preschool-aged children like this patient, methylphenidate is only used if first-line treatment is not met with an adequate response.

question_text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician because her mother has found her to be inattentive at home and has received multiple complaints from her teachers at school. She does not complete her assignments and does not listen to her teachers' instructions. She refuses to talk to her parents or peers. Her mother says, “She ignores everything I say to her!” She prefers playing alone, and her mother reports that she likes playing with 5 red toy cars, repeatedly arranging them in a straight line. She avoids eye contact with her mother and the physician throughout the visit. Physical and neurological examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician because her mother has found her to be inattentive at home and has received multiple complaints from her teachers at school. She does not complete her assignments and does not listen to her teachers' instructions. She refuses to talk to her parents or peers. Her mother says, “She ignores everything I say to her!” She prefers playing alone, and her mother reports that she likes playing with 5 red toy cars, repeatedly arranging them in a straight line. She avoids eye contact with her mother and the physician throughout the visit. Physical and neurological examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Early intervention programs can improve communication and social skills for patients with this disorder.
learning_objective: Recognize autism spectrum disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Like the patient here, patients with ADHD typically present with difficulties paying attention and have poor academic performance. However, ADHD is also characterized by impulsiveness and hyperactivity, which are not present in this patient. Moreover, language problems such as maladaptive speech, repetitive/stereotyped behavior, and fixated interests suggest a different diagnosis.

Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by anger, irritable mood, and defiant behavior toward figures of authority, which may also cause problems at school, for ≥ 6 months. Although this patient does not listen to her teachers or her mother, she does not argue with or act out against them.

Fragile X syndrome presents with intellectual disability, language delay, and characteristic physical features, including large ears and a thin, elongated face. It predominantly affects male patients, as heterozygous female carriers of the defective FMR1 gene can compensate for the defect if their second X chromosome is normal. Although this patient's refusal to speak could be a sign of language delay, the fact that she is female and has normal physical examination findings make this diagnosis unlikely.

Although clinical presentation varies widely, autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is characterized by impairment in social interaction and restrictive patterns of behavior or interests. This patient's trouble communicating, inattentiveness, refusal to speak and make eye contact, fixation on and intense attachment to certain objects (red toy cars), and repeated actions are all behaviors typically seen in patients with ASD. While the exact cause of ASD is unknown, twin studies strongly suggest a genetic predisposition.

Treatment of ASD, which should be initiated early, involves educational and behavioral management (e.g., competence training for social skills and communication skills), family counseling, and medical therapy (e.g., SSRIs for repetitive stereotyped behavior).

A child with hearing impairment may appear to be inattentive or unresponsive when spoken to. However, a diagnosis of hearing impairment would not explain the other features of this patient's behavioral pattern, including her refusal to speak or make eye contact, her intense attachment to certain specific objects (red toy cars), and the frequent repetition of specific actions. She also has no history of the most common risk factors for childhood hearing loss (ear infections, malformations, obstructions, or ototoxic drug intake).

This patient's behavior does not meet the diagnostic criteria for conduct disorder, which include aggression (e.g., arguing with teachers, cruelty to animals), propensity to criminal behavior (e.g., destruction of property and theft), and serious rule violation. While this patient's behavior could be interpreted as defiant and she does have problems at school, her behavior is neither aggressive nor deceitful, and she has not engaged in property damage or seriously violated any rules.

Patients with Rett syndrome initially meet developmental milestones before experiencing a progressive loss of cognitive and fine motor skills beginning at 7–24 months of age. Pronounced verbal disability is common, and patients may show characteristic hand wringing. Although this patient refuses to speak, her fine motor skills are developmentally appropriate and her history is not consistent with developmental regression.

Children with normal language development speak in three-word sentences by age 3 and recount complex stories by age 4. This patient's behavior is not normal for a 5-year-old child. Being inattentive, ignoring what other people say, and preferring to play alone might be age-appropriate to a certain degree. However, this patient's avoidance of eye contact, refusal to speak, and frequent repetition of specific actions point to a different diagnosis.

question_text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of repetitive, involuntary blinking, shrugging, and grunting for the past year. His mother states that his symptoms improve when he is physically active, while tiredness, boredom, and stress aggravate them. He has felt increasingly embarrassed by his symptoms in school, and his grades have been dropping from average levels. He has met all his developmental milestones. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows intact higher mental functioning and thought processes. Excessive blinking, grunting, and jerking of the shoulders and neck occur while at rest. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely to develop in this patient?
content_preview: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of repetitive, involuntary blinking, shrugging, and grunting for the past year. His mother states that his symptoms improve when he is physically active, while tiredness, boredom, and stress aggravate them. He has felt increasingly embarrassed by his symptoms in school, and his grades have been dropping from average levels. He has met all his developmental milestones. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows intact higher mental functioning and thought processes. Excessive blinking, grunting, and jerking of the shoulders and neck occur while at rest. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely to develop in this patient?
hint: This patient's presentation of involuntary blinking, shrugging, and grunting in combination with a normal physical examination indicates Tourette syndrome, which has a high incidence of comorbidities.
learning_objective: Recognize Tourette syndrome, and recall its common comorbidities.

answers.explanation_why: Excessive impulsivity, as well as hyperactivity and inattention with impairment of social, occupational, or academic performance are the core features of attention deficit hyperactive disorder (ADHD). About 60% of patients with Tourette syndrome develop concomitant ADHD, making it the most common comorbidity. Obsessive-compulsive disorders (OCD) are also common in patients with Tourette syndrome.

answers.content: Defiant and hostile behavior toward teachers and parents
answers.explanation_why: Defiant and hostile behavior toward teachers and parents is a classic feature of oppositional defiant disorders. Behavioral problems must persist over a period of ≥ 6 months to make the diagnosis. This patient most likely has Tourette syndrome, which is associated with numerous neuropsychiatric conditions, including oppositional defiant disorders and conduct disorders (15% of cases). However, another childhood neuropsychiatric condition is much more common, occurring in 60% of patients with Tourette syndrome.

Dyscalculia is a specific learning disorder that is characterized by problems processing numerical information, learning arithmetic facts, and performing accurate or fluent calculations. Learning disorders may occur in isolation or in association with other neuropsychiatric disorders. Although learning disabilities occur in more than 20% of patients with Tourette syndrome, they are generally associated with concomitant ADHD rather than the tics themselves.

answers.content: Feelings of persistent sadness and loss of interest
answers.explanation_why: This boy most likely has Tourette syndrome, which has a high incidence of psychiatric comorbidities. Patients often express shame and anxiety regarding their tics. It is not, however, associated with an increased risk for major depression disorder (MDD).

Chorea and hyperreflexia are features of Huntington disease (HD). This neurodegenerative condition is an important differential diagnosis of Tourette syndrome since it is also a movement disorder characterized by involuntary and irregular movements of the limbs, neck, head, and/or face. Chorea movements are generally unpredictable and arrhythmic or nonrepetitive, while tic movements due to Tourette syndrome are generally repeated and stereotypical. Furthermore, HD is an autosomal-dominant inherited disease that typically manifests at the age of 40 years. Childhood onset is rare and this patient does not have a family history of HD.

Recurrent episodes of intense fear, accompanied by vegetative symptoms (sweating, nausea, difficulty breathing, tachycardia) are characteristic for panic attacks. Although patients with Tourette syndrome may develop anxiety disorders such as panic attacks, another childhood neuropsychiatric condition is much more common, occurring in 60% of patients with Tourette syndrome.

question_text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of repetitive involuntary movements, including neck twisting, grimacing, grunting, and blinking, for the past 18 months. Her father reports that her symptoms seem to improve with concentration and worsen when she is tired. During the past 3 months, her symptoms have become so severe that she has missed many school days. She also has too much anxiety about her involuntary movements to see her friends and prefers staying home in her room. Her birth and development until 18 months ago were normal. The father has bipolar disorder. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows intact higher mental function and thought processes. Neurologic examination shows multiple motor and vocal tics. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of repetitive involuntary movements, including neck twisting, grimacing, grunting, and blinking, for the past 18 months. Her father reports that her symptoms seem to improve with concentration and worsen when she is tired. During the past 3 months, her symptoms have become so severe that she has missed many school days. She also has too much anxiety about her involuntary movements to see her friends and prefers staying home in her room. Her birth and development until 18 months ago were normal. The father has bipolar disorder. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows intact higher mental function and thought processes. Neurologic examination shows multiple motor and vocal tics. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
hint: This patient's involuntary vocal and motor tics indicate Tourette syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Tourette syndrome, and choose the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Buspirone is an anxiolytic indicated for the treatment of anxiety disorders (e.g., generalized anxiety disorder, social phobia), depression, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), and symptoms of irritability and aggression. It is not a first-line treatment for tics or Tourette syndrome.

Alprazolam is a benzodiazepine used primarily to treat generalized anxiety disorder, panic disorder, night terrors, insomnia and alcohol withdrawal syndrome. It is not recommended for the treatment of Tourette syndrome and may also have side effects that aggravate its symptoms, including agitation, hyperactivity, twitches, and tremors.

Guanfacine and clonidine are alpha-2 adrenergic agonists commonly used for managing tics (e.g., in Tourette syndrome) in children and adolescents, especially in those with comorbid ADHD or anxiety. Alpha-2 adrenergic agonists have a more favorable side effect profile than dopamine receptor antagonists like haloperidol and aripiprazole. Additional treatment options include topiramate and vesicular monoamine transporter type 2 inhibitors such as tetrabenazine, but there is limited evidence to support their use. Comprehensive behavioral intervention for tics (CBIT) is recommended in all patients with functional impairment, and pharmacotherapy is warranted when tics significantly interfere with daily functioning or if CBIT alone is ineffective.

Fluoxetine is an SSRI used to treat depression, anxiety disorders, obsessive-compulsive disorders, and somatic symptom disorder. While Tourette syndrome may be associated with anxiety disorders and obsessive-compulsive disorders and therefore may show some improvement with fluoxetine treatment, it is not recommended as a first-line treatment for the underlying condition.

Chlorpromazine is a low-potency antipsychotic that is primarily indicated for schizophrenia, the manic phase of bipolar disorder, and short-term treatment of anxiety (e.g., prior to surgery). While some antipsychotics might be used to treat Tourette syndrome, chlorpromazine is not recommended.

question_text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of worsening grades over the past year. Since she started high school one year ago, her academic performance has decreased. She also has had difficulty finding friends at the new school. She is afraid that her classmates will make fun of her and think that she is “stupid.” One month ago, when she had to give a presentation, she could not stop worrying about how her classmates were going to react if she said something wrong. During the presentation, her heart started racing and she became flushed. Since this event, she has avoided saying anything in class. She spends her breaks in the restroom because she is worried that nobody will talk to her. Physical and neurological examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, the girl avoids eye contact and appears uncomfortable and anxious. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of worsening grades over the past year. Since she started high school one year ago, her academic performance has decreased. She also has had difficulty finding friends at the new school. She is afraid that her classmates will make fun of her and think that she is “stupid.” One month ago, when she had to give a presentation, she could not stop worrying about how her classmates were going to react if she said something wrong. During the presentation, her heart started racing and she became flushed. Since this event, she has avoided saying anything in class. She spends her breaks in the restroom because she is worried that nobody will talk to her. Physical and neurological examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, the girl avoids eye contact and appears uncomfortable and anxious. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?
hint: Persistent fear, anxiety, and/or avoidance related to social settings (e.g., school lunch break) and performance situations (e.g., giving a classroom presentation) that results in significant distress and academic impairment (e.g., worsening grades) for ≥ 6 months is consistent with social anxiety disorder (SAD).
learning_objective: Recognize social anxiety disorder, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Because of its serotonergic properties, clomipramine, a tricyclic antidepressant, may be beneficial in patients with SAD, especially in patients with concurrent depression. However, there have not been enough clinical studies to recommend its use as a first-line agent in this patient group.

Phenelzine, a monoamine oxidase inhibitor, is used to treat patients with SAD (esp. those with a history of substance abuse) who do not respond well to first-line pharmacotherapy. Long-term use of phenelzine can cause complications such as hypotension, insomnia, sedation, weight gain, and sexual dysfunction.

Quetiapine, an antipsychotic, is useful in treating patients with generalized anxiety disorder who do not respond to other pharmacotherapy. There is not currently sufficient evidence to recommend the use of quetiapine in patients with SAD.

Clonazepam, a benzodiazepine, is used as an anxiolytic in patients with SAD who do not respond to cognitive behavioral therapy or first-line pharmacotherapy. Intermittent, as-needed use of clonazepam is helpful in treating performance-only SAD and panic disorder. Benzodiazepines can cause physical dependence and are not considered a first-line drug in patients who need long-term therapy, such as this patient.

Pharmacotherapy with either selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as fluoxetine, or selective serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), such as venlafaxine, or cognitive behavioral therapy are the first-line management options for social anxiety disorder. Patients with minimal response to SSRIs or SNRIs can be given a trial of either long-acting benzodiazepines (e.g., clonazepam) if they have no history of substance abuse, or irreversible monoamine oxidase inhibitors (e.g., phenelzine) if they have a history of harmful substance use. For patients with performance-only SAD, cognitive behavioral therapy and/or intermittent beta blocker therapy is preferred.

Propranolol, a beta blocker, is useful in controlling symptoms of SAD such as tachycardia and tremor. Beta blockers are currently recommended only as an intermittent therapy, on an as-needed basis, for performance-only SAD. This child presents with anxiety associated with all social interactions, not just performance-related events, therefore intermittent therapy would not be adequate for this patient.

Buspirone, an anxiolytic drug, is useful as a monotherapy in nondepressed patients with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). Buspirone is not effective as a monotherapy for patients with SAD but can be used in patients with SAD who show some response to an SSRI to augment its effect. In contrast to patients with SAD, patients with GAD are usually comfortable in social situations and are not disturbed by the evaluation by others.

question_text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician because her mother is concerned about her lack of appetite. She has had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss over the past 4 months. The patient states that she does not “feel like eating so much.” Over the last year, her academic performance in school has decreased, and she has had a lot of disputes with her parents concerning her future. Her mother says that she has also become more nervous and restless. Her grandmother had a problem with her thyroid. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She is at the 60^th percentile for height, 30^th percentile for weight, and 20^th percentile for BMI. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 104/min, and blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. The pupils are 9 mm large, round and minimally reactive to light. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. There is fine tremor of her hands. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
content_preview: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician because her mother is concerned about her lack of appetite. She has had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss over the past 4 months. The patient states that she does not “feel like eating so much.” Over the last year, her academic performance in school has decreased, and she has had a lot of disputes with her parents concerning her future. Her mother says that she has also become more nervous and restless. Her grandmother had a problem with her thyroid. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She is at the 60th percentile for height, 30th percentile for weight, and 20th percentile for BMI. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 104/min, and blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. The pupils are 9 mm large, round and minimally reactive to light. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. There is fine tremor of her hands. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
hint: A pupillary diameter of > 5 mm during eye examination with a light is abnormally large.
learning_objective: Recognize features of sympathomimetic drug intoxication, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Recent onset of weight loss in a young woman should raise suspicion of anorexia nervosa. Because rapid weight loss (e.g., due to vomiting, severely reduced food intake) can lead to critical electrolyte imbalances, serum electrolyte levels should be measured. However, this patient's BMI (BMI not < 10^th percentile) excludes this diagnosis of anorexia nervosa.

An abdominal ultrasound in a patient with a history of weight loss may be indicated to rule out gastrointestinal conditions (e.g., Crohn disease) or malignancies. In this young woman with no other symptoms besides recent weight loss, abdominal ultrasound is not the first step in management.

Toxicology screening is performed to confirm the presence of drugs in a urine or blood sample. This patient presents with features of sympathomimetic drug intoxication (e.g., with cocaine, amphetamines), including tachycardia, mydriasis, and tremor of the hands. Her recent decline in academic performance, increased number of conflicts with her family, weight loss, and nervousness indicate chronic drug use consistent with a substance use disorder. While a positive toxicology screening confirms the recent use of cocaine, it does not establish the diagnosis of a substance use disorder, which requires fulfillment of the DSM-5 diagnostic criteria (e.g., impaired control, social impairment, risky use).

Measurement of TSH, fT3, and fT4 is indicated in individuals with suspected thyroid disorders. This patient has a family history of thyroid disorders and shows features that could indicate hyperthyroidism, including weight loss, tachycardia, tremor of the hands, and agitation. However, the dilated pupils, decreased appetite, and normal deep tendon reflexes (hyper-reflexive in hyperthyroidism) make a different diagnosis more likely.

An MRI of the brain is indicated in patients with suspected intracranial pathologies (e.g., abscess, brain tumor). While patients with CNS lesions may present with minimally reactive pupils (due to increased ICP) and behavioral changes, they usually also present with headaches, seizures, or focal motor or sensory deficits. This patient's nervousness, mydriasis, and fine tremor of her hands is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

Given her history of unprotected intercourse with multiple partners, an HIV test should be offered to this patient. However, it is not the next best step in diagnosis. While reduced appetite and weight loss may occur in AIDS, this patient's enlarged pupils and tremor of the hands are not usually seen.

question_text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of increasingly withdrawn behavior for the last two years. His mother reports that in the last 2–3 years of high school, her son has spent most of his time in his room playing video games. He does not have any friends and has never had a partner. He usually refuses to attend family dinner and avoids contact with his siblings. The patient states that he prefers being on his own. When asked how much playing video games means to him, he replies that “it's okay.” When his mother starts crying during the visit, he appears indifferent. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. On mental status examination, his thought process is organized and logical. His affect is flattened. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

He usually refuses to attend family dinner and avoids contact with his siblings. The patient states that he prefers being on his own. When asked how much playing video games means to him, he replies that “it's okay.” When his mother starts crying during the visit, he appears indifferent. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. On mental status examination, his thought process is organized and logical. His affect is flattened. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with a rare cluster A personality disorder that has some similarities with the negative symptoms of schizophrenia.
learning_objective: Recognize schizoid personality disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by constricted affect and a lack of close friends due to acute discomfort in social interactions and impaired capacity for close relationships. However, further symptoms include distortions of perception and cognition (e.g., magical thinking, superstitions), as well as eccentric behavior (e.g., peculiar speech), which are not present in this patient.

Schizophreniform disorder is diagnosed in patients who present with delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and/or negative symptoms that last for more than 1 month but less than 6 months. This patient presents with different symptoms that have been affecting him for over 6 months.

This patient has signs of social withdrawal, a preference for solitary activities, and flattened affect, all of which are features of schizoid personality disorder. Individuals with schizoid personality disorder neither desire nor enjoy close relationships. They show little interest in interpersonal or sexual contact and often appear indifferent or emotionally cold towards others (see “Overview of cluster A personality disorders” table). Of note, the DSM-5 states that personality disorders can be diagnosed in patients < 18 years of age if features have been present for ≥ 1 year. The only exception to this rule is antisocial personality disorder, which can only be diagnosed in patients ≥ 18 years of age.

Personality disorders are characterized by pervasive, inflexible, and maladaptive patterns of relating to and perceiving one's self and one's environment that cause significant distress and/or functional impairment. These patterns typically arise during early adolescence, remain stable over time, and are difficult to treat. Treatment options include psychoeducation, psychotherapy, dialectical behavior therapy, group therapy, and/or cognitive therapy.

Antisocial personality disorder is characterized by lack of empathy and incapacity for intimacy. However, patients are also prone to deceitful, manipulative, and impulsive behavior and they disregard laws and ethical norms if this provides them personal profit or pleasure. Furthermore, the diagnosis can only be made if the individual is ≥ 18 years of age and there is evidence of conduct disorder prior to 15 years of age.

Individuals with avoidant personality disorder tend to avoid social interactions, but they do this in spite of a wish to establish social relationships because of extreme anxiety and shyness in social situations brought on by feelings of inadequacy and fear of rejection. This patient does not have an inhibited desire to establish personal relationships.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is characterized by impaired social interaction and communication as well as stereotyped behavior, interests, and activities. Reduced ability for empathy and response in social situations could raise the suspicion of ASD, but symptoms of this disorder are typically recognized in early childhood (2–3 years of age) rather than adolescence.

Social anxiety disorder is characterized by pronounced anxiety and avoidance of social situations that lasts ≥ 6 months. It often develops during adolescence and early adulthood, when patients develop a fear of becoming scrutinized in social situations such as speaking or eating in public. While this patient avoids social interaction, there are no signs to suggest that he is driven to do so by social anxiety or that he suffers from his isolation.

Internet gaming disorder is included in the DSM-5 under the chapter “Conditions for further study”. While this patient might meet the proposed criterion of a preoccupation with internet games, his involvement in gaming is below the threshold of the other criteria (e.g., withdrawal symptoms, tolerance, unsuccessful attempts to control gaming habit) and his other symptoms rather suggest a different diagnosis.

Individuals with paranoid personality disorder tend to be socially withdrawn, as this patient is, but they are withdrawn due to a severe distrust and suspiciousness rooted in the notion that others harbor malicious intentions against them. They often perceive even insignificant incidents as directed against them and are quick to perceive attacks on their character that are not apparent to others.

question_text: A 19-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother because she is worried about his strange behavior. Over the past 3 years, he has been dressing all in black and wears a long black coat, even in the summer. The mother reports that her son has always had difficulties fitting in. He does not have any friends and spends most of his time in his room playing online games. He is anxious at college because he is uncomfortable around other people, and his academic performance is poor. Rather than doing his coursework, he spends most of his time reading up on paranormal phenomena, especially demons. He says that he has never seen any demons, but sometimes there are signs of their presence. For example, a breeze in an enclosed room is likely the “breath of a demon.” Mental status examination shows laborious speech. The patient avoids eye contact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 19-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother because she is worried about his strange behavior. Over the past 3 years, he has been dressing all in black and wears a long black coat, even in the summer. The mother reports that her son has always had difficulties fitting in. He does not have any friends and spends most of his time in his room playing online games. He is anxious at college because he is uncomfortable around other people, and his academic performance is poor. Rather than doing his coursework, he spends most of his time reading up on paranormal phenomena, especially demons. He says that he has never seen any demons, but sometimes there are signs of their presence. For example, a breeze in an enclosed room is likely the “breath of a demon.” Mental status examination shows laborious speech. The patient avoids eye contact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient has a cluster A personality disorder.
learning_objective: Recognize schizotypal personality disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with schizoid personality disorder present with eccentric behavior and difficulty developing meaningful social relationships. However, a key component of schizoid personality disorder is a pervasive pattern of social withdrawal and limited range of emotional expression. Patients are content with social isolation and do not seek relationships. Although this patient does not have friends and spends most of his time alone, patients with schizoid personality disorder would be more indifferent about social interactions than anxious. Furthermore, this patient's interest in paranormal phenomena, magical thinking, and eccentric clothing would not be explained by this diagnosis.

Patients with social anxiety disorder have anxiety in social situations. However, their anxiety is driven by an intense fear of embarrassment in social situations. Furthermore, this patient's odd beliefs, magical thinking, and unusual clothing could not be explained by this disorder.

Patients with avoidant personality disorder are uncomfortable around other people and avoid social settings. Their discomfort is driven by a feeling of inadequacy and/or an intense fear of rejection or embarrassment, and they tend to desire interpersonal relationships even if they are anxious about interacting with others. However, this patient's social withdrawal appears voluntary and his odd beliefs and unusual clothing choices would not be explained by this diagnosis.

Schizotypal personality disorder usually manifests with odd and eccentric behavior and appearance. Patients also tend to have odd beliefs or magical thinking that are inconsistent with cultural norms. Moreover, excessive social anxiety, odd speech, inappropriate affect, and lack of close friends are usually also seen.

See “Overview of cluster A personality disorders” table.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is usually diagnosed in young children who present with persistent impairment in communication and social interaction as well as restricted, stereotyped patterns of behavior, interests, and activities. Although this young man is uncomfortable around other people, his age and the absence of additional symptoms of ASD, including impaired language skills or repetitive movements and behavior, makes the diagnosis unlikely. The diagnosis of ASD would also not explain this patient's preoccupation with paranormal phenomena.

Patients with paranoid personality disorder are generally emotionally isolated and have eccentric behavior. However, a key component of paranoid personality disorder is suspicion of and distrust toward others due to the belief that others have malicious intentions. Although this patient is uncomfortable around other people, he is not described as being suspicious of them. Furthermore, paranoid personality disorder is not typically associated with odd and magical thinking.

Patients with schizophrenia present with chronic and recurrent psychosis for more than 6 months. These patients tend to initially present with a prodrome of negative symptoms characterized by social withdrawal, which is then followed by positive psychotic symptoms (i.e., hallucinations, delusions, and bizarre behaviors). Although this patient prefers to be alone and has odd beliefs, he does not meet the criteria for the diagnosis of schizophrenia, as he has no clear delusions or hallucinations and no disorganized speech.

This patient's laborious speech is not the same as disorganized speech. Laborious speech is nonfluent speech that requires excessive effort and lacks spontaneity, but the thought processes and the contents of the speech are intact. On the other hand, disorganized speech results from disorganized thought processes and can manifest as loose associations (illogical, sudden, and frequent changes of topic), word salad (sequence of words without a logical connection), and flight of ideas (quick succession of thoughts), none of which are evident in this patient.

question_text: Twenty-four hours after delivery, a 2888-g (6-lb 6-oz) male newborn is not feeding well, has a high-pitched cry, and is diaphoretic. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation to a 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, after an uncomplicated delivery. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother did not receive prenatal care. She takes codeine syrup frequently for dry cough. The infant's temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 165/min, and blood pressure is 83/50 mm Hg. Examination shows hyperreflexia, tremors, and an excessive startle response. The baby is swaddled to prevent excoriations, and fluid resuscitation is initiated, which provides only minimal improvement in his symptoms. Complete blood count and serum levels of glucose, bilirubin, and calcium are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this newborn?
content_preview: Twenty-four hours after delivery, a 2888-g (6-lb 6-oz) male newborn is not feeding well, has a high-pitched cry, and is diaphoretic. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation to a 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, after an uncomplicated delivery. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother did not receive prenatal care. She takes codeine syrup frequently for dry cough. The infant's temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 165/min, and blood pressure is 83/50 mm Hg. Examination shows hyperreflexia, tremors, and an excessive startle response. The baby is swaddled to prevent excoriations, and fluid resuscitation is initiated, which provides only minimal improvement in his symptoms. Complete blood count and serum levels of glucose, bilirubin, and calcium are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this newborn?
hint: This neonate, whose mother has a history of opioid use, presents with gastrointestinal symptoms (poor feeding), flu-like symptoms (sweating, fever), and CNS stimulation (high-pitched crying, irritability, hyperreflexia, tremors) within 24 hours of birth. These features are associated with opioid withdrawal and suggest a diagnosis of neonatal abstinence syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal abstinence syndrome, and choose the most appropriate pharmacological treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Management of neonatal abstinence syndrome includes supportive care (e.g., swaddling, IV fluids, reduced sensory stimulation), which is often sufficient in infants with mild symptoms. In moderate to severe cases (e.g., inability to sleep or feed, severe diarrhea with dehydration) or if supportive treatment is unsuccessful, as seen here, opioid replacement is indicated to treat the withdrawal and ensure that infants can gain weight. First-line pharmacological treatment options include oral morphine, buprenorphine, and methadone. Second-line treatment includes phenobarbital and clonidine.

Oral clonidine may be used in the treatment of neonatal abstinence syndrome. Clonidine reduces noradrenergic hyperactivity and autonomic symptoms without causing respiratory depression. However, it is not currently recommended as first-line treatment; an alternate therapy is more effective for this patient's condition.

IV calcium gluconate is used to treat hypocalcemia, which may also manifest with irritability, poor feeding, tremors, and hyperreflexia in infants. However, this infant does not have any risk factors for hypocalcemia (e.g., preterm birth, intrauterine growth restriction) and his serum calcium level is normal.

Therapeutic hypothermia is used to treat neonatal encephalopathy. While mild cases may also present with irritability, hyperreflexia, crying, and poor feeding, this infant does not have any risk factors for this disease (e.g., drop in maternal blood pressure causing cerebral hypoxia).

A combination of IV ampicillin and gentamicin can be used to treat certain neonatal infections (e.g., meningitis). While the presentation in infants can be nonspecific and similar to those seen here, the absence of leukocytosis and lack of risk factors for neonatal infection (e.g., maternal infection, premature birth) make this diagnosis unlikely.
Dextrose infusion is used to treat neonatal hypoglycemia, which may present with similar symptoms (e.g., irritability, sweating, poor feeding). However, this patient's glucose level is normal.

question_text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 10-month history of repeated behavioral problems. Her teachers describe her behavior as uncooperative and disruptive as she persistently refuses to answer questions, insults her teachers, and deliberately distracts her classmates. At home, her parents try to address her frequent violations of curfew but attempts to discuss the issue often result in their daughter losing her temper and screaming at her parents. Her grades have deteriorated over the past year. When listening to music or hanging out with friends, she is calm and pleasant. She has no history of psychiatric illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurological examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is uncooperative and frequently disrupts the physician’s conversation with the parents. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 10-month history of repeated behavioral problems. Her teachers describe her behavior as uncooperative and disruptive as she persistently refuses to answer questions, insults her teachers, and deliberately distracts her classmates. At home, her parents try to address her frequent violations of curfew but attempts to discuss the issue often result in their daughter losing her temper and screaming at her parents. Her grades have deteriorated over the past year. When listening to music or hanging out with friends, she is calm and pleasant. She has no history of psychiatric illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurological examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is uncooperative and frequently disrupts the physician’s conversation with the parents. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This teenager shows overly disruptive behavior toward figures of authority.
learning_objective: Recognize oppositional defiant disorder (ODD).

answers.explanation_why: Reactive attachment disorder does not result in temper tantrums or disruptive behavior. Instead, it is characterized by a consistent pattern of inhibited, emotionally withdrawn behavior toward caregivers or peers and a flat affect. Children with reactive attachment disorder usually have a history of parental neglect or foster care, which is not the case here. Moreover, a diagnosis of reactive attachment disorder cannot be made unless the onset of symptoms occurs before the age of 5 years.

Conduct disorder is common during adolescence and may present with temper tantrums and disruptive behavior at home and school. However, patients with conduct disorder also have repetitive and persistent behavior that violates the basic rights of others and important age-appropriate societal norms, e.g., deceitfulness, stealing, property destruction, and violence, which is not present in this patient.

Patients with a disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD) have recurrent temper tantrums both at home and at school. However, patients with DMDD are persistently angry or irritable in between these outbursts, which is not the case in this patient. Moreover, a diagnosis of DMDD cannot be made unless the symptoms have been ongoing for ≥ 12 months and the onset of symptoms occurs before the age of 10 years.

Patients with antisocial personality disorder are impulsive, violent, and deceitful. They remorselessly disregard the basic rights of others. Such behavior is not present in this patient. Moreover, a diagnosis of antisocial personality disorder cannot be made until the person is 18 years of age.

Patients with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) are often described as “uncooperative” and “disruptive” by their teachers because they have difficulty remaining seated, quietly engaging in activities, and not interrupting other students in their activities. Difficulties sustaining attention can lead to an increased rate of mistakes and a deterioration of academic performance. However, unlike this child who defiantly refuses to answer questions, children with ADHD have difficulties controlling their impulse to talk and tend to answer out of turn. Moreover, temper tantrums and insulting behavior are not typical features of ADHD and the diagnosis of the condition can only be made if the onset of symptoms occurs before the age of 12 years.

Disruptive behavior and occasional temper tantrums can be a part of normal adolescent development. However, such behavior is considered pathological when it is frequent, persistent, and impairs the functioning of the individual and of others (e.g., peers, teachers, parents).

This patient's irritable mood, deliberately annoying peers, and defiant behavior toward authority figures without serious violation of social norms are consistent with oppositional defiant disorder (ODD). The frequency of this behavior, more than once per week, goes beyond what is normative for children of her age. Furthermore, the ≥ 6-month duration of symptoms fulfills the diagnostic criteria for ODD.

Individuals with ODD are negatively impacted in numerous areas important for normal functioning (e.g., social, educational, occupational), and the hostility they express is toward individuals within their immediate social circle (e.g., family members, peers, work colleagues, teachers). Therefore, peer group support and peer-mediated interventions, alongside psychotherapy, parent management training, and social-skills programs, are pivotal in treating ODD.

question_text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of teacher complaints regarding his poor performance at school for the past 8 months. He has difficulty sustaining attention when assigned school-related tasks, does not follow the teachers' instructions, and makes careless mistakes in his homework. He often blurts out answers in class and has difficulty adhering to the rules during soccer practice. His mother reports that he is easily distracted when she speaks with him and that he often forgets his books at school. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is started on the appropriate first-line therapy. This boy is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
content_preview: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of teacher complaints regarding his poor performance at school for the past 8 months. He has difficulty sustaining attention when assigned school-related tasks, does not follow the teachers' instructions, and makes careless mistakes in his homework. He often blurts out answers in class and has difficulty adhering to the rules during soccer practice. His mother reports that he is easily distracted when she speaks with him and that he often forgets his books at school. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is started on the appropriate first-line therapy. This boy is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
hint: This patient's symptoms of inattention and hyperactivity/impulsivity present in more than one setting (at home, in school, soccer practice), onset of symptoms before 12 years of age, and duration of symptoms for ≥ 6 months fulfill the diagnostic criteria for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Methylphenidate is one of the most commonly used first-line medications.
learning_objective: Recognize attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), and recall the side effects of methylphenidate.

answers.explanation_why: A prolonged QT interval can be caused by antiarrhythmic drugs (e.g., amiodarone), antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol), antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline), phenothiazines, and first-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine). While the medication used for this patient's condition may induce tachycardia, it is not associated with a prolonged QT interval.

Serotonin syndrome is a condition caused by intake of serotonergic drugs (e.g., SSRIs). While it may present with some symptoms similar to the adverse effects caused by the medication given to this boy, serotonergic drugs are not indicated in the treatment of his condition.

Common medications that increase appetite or reduce metabolism and lead to weight gain include antipsychotics and antidepressants, which are not indicated in the treatment of the patient's condition. The medication he is receiving typically reduces appetite and can lead to weight loss.

Medications that may impair liver function and lead to an elevation of transaminases include acetaminophen, statins, and some anticonvulsants (e.g., valproate) and antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin). The medication this patient is receiving is not known to impair liver function.

Decreased perspiration is an adverse effect of anticholinergics (antimuscarinic agents) which are used to suppress functions of the parasympathetic nervous system (e.g., in the treatment of asthma, urinary incontinence). The first-line treatment given for this boy's condition typically has a sympathomimetic effect and increases perspiration.

This boy is most likely being treated with methylphenidate, which is first-line pharmacotherapy for ADHD. Methylphenidate has sympathomimetic activity and improves concentration, cognition, and short-term memory. Common adverse sympathomimetic effects include elevated arterial blood pressure, tachycardia, sweating, insomnia, decreased seizure threshold, and a reduced appetite/stunted growth.

question_text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of 2 episodes of screaming in the night over the past week. The parents report that their son woke up suddenly screaming, crying, and aggressively kicking his legs around both times. The episodes lasted several minutes and were accompanied by sweating and fast breathing. The parents state that they were unable to stop the episodes and that their son simply went back to sleep when the episodes were over. The patient cannot recall any details of these incidents. He has a history of obstructive sleep apnea. He takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of 2 episodes of screaming in the night over the past week. The parents report that their son woke up suddenly screaming, crying, and aggressively kicking his legs around both times. The episodes lasted several minutes and were accompanied by sweating and fast breathing. The parents state that they were unable to stop the episodes and that their son simply went back to sleep when the episodes were over. The patient cannot recall any details of these incidents. He has a history of obstructive sleep apnea. He takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Obstructive sleep apnea is associated with this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize sleep terror disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Insomnia disorder is characterized by problems initiating and/or maintaining sleep, or waking up very early and being unable to return to sleep; symptoms occur ≥ 3 days/week for ≥ 3 months. However, the fearful incomplete arousal from sleep affecting this child is not a feature of insomnia disorder.

Delayed sleep phase disorder is a type of circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorder in which the patient is unable to fall asleep and awake at conventional sleep times (delay is usually > 2 hours), although the quality and duration of sleep may be normal (e.g., patient sleeps from 02:00 AM–10:00 AM). This condition is more common in adolescents than young children and the abrupt, fearful incomplete arousal from sleep that this child presents with is not seen in delayed sleep phase disorder.

Restless legs syndrome (RLS) is characterized by an urge to move the legs, especially at night when either awake or asleep. RLS is uncommon in young children, however, and does not cause the other features seen in this child.

Sleep terror disorder is a type of parasomnia in which children present with abrupt, incomplete arousal from sleep, screaming, crying, and/or trying to escape from an unseen threat. It also typically involves sympathetic hyperactivity (mydriasis, sweating, tachycardia, tachypnea), unresponsiveness to efforts at calming, and no recollection of the event on waking. The condition is usually self-limited. Sharp/potentially harmful objects should be kept away from the bedroom of the patient. Benzodiazepines may be helpful in refractory cases.

Nightmare disorder is a type of parasomnia that occurs in rapid eye movement (REM) sleep and is typically seen in adults. In contrast to this child, patients with nightmare disorder remember the dream vividly and can be easily roused during a nightmare episode. Vocalizations such as screaming or crying are not common in nightmare disorder (because of REM sleep-induced skeletal muscle tone loss).

Sleepwalking disorder is a type of parasomnia that occurs in NREM sleep and is typically seen in young children. This condition is associated with obstructive sleep apnea, and the patient often cannot remember the episode once fully awake. Also, it is difficult to wake up a patient during an episode. However, patients with sleepwalking disorder often have a blank stare during the episode of incomplete arousal from sleepwalking and are not agitated/distressed. For this reason, it is unlikely that this child has sleepwalking disorder.

question_text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of difficulty sleeping for the past 2 months. One to two times per week, she wakes up frightened and anxious in the middle of the night. She does not seem to be confused after waking, is consolable, and is able to fall back asleep in her parents' bed. The following day, she seems more tired than usual at school. She recalls details of her bad dream and looks for ways to delay bedtime in the evenings. She has met all of her developmental milestones to date. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of difficulty sleeping for the past 2 months. One to two times per week, she wakes up frightened and anxious in the middle of the night. She does not seem to be confused after waking, is consolable, and is able to fall back asleep in her parents' bed. The following day, she seems more tired than usual at school. She recalls details of her bad dream and looks for ways to delay bedtime in the evenings. She has met all of her developmental milestones to date. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This disorder usually occurs in the REM stage of sleep.
learning_objective: Recognize nightmare disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with sleep terror disorder also experience nightmares. However, unlike this girl, these patients are difficult to wake, show autonomic responses (e.g., tachycardia, diaphoresis) while dreaming, and generally cannot recall the content of their dreams. In addition, sleep terror disorder occurs in the first half of the sleep cycle, whereas this patient wakes in the second half (midnight).

Individuals with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) may experience recurrent nightmares as one of the intrusive symptoms of the disorder. However, this patient does not exhibit other criteria of PTSD such as altered reactivity to stimuli or a negative impact on her mood or cognition. Additionally, there is nothing in her history to suggest exposure to a prior traumatic event.

Although many children experience nightmares, the frequency of this girl's nighttime awakenings and her reduction in sleep quality, as well as increased daytime fatigue, avoidance of bedtime, and negative impact on the family (i.e., nighttime disruptions) are not consistent with normal development.

This patient's recurrent frightening dreams during the second half of the sleep cycle (midnight) are consistent with nightmare disorder. Individuals with nightmare disorder can be easily roused during an episode and can vividly remember their dreams. Nightmares are usually accompanied by negative emotions such as fear and anxiety. Functional impairment (e.g., this patient's fatigue at school) and distress are also common. Reassurance is the first-line treatment for mild cases of nightmare disorder.

Although this patient seems to find comfort from falling asleep in her parents' bed after having a nightmare, she does not display the characteristics of separation anxiety disorder, which would involve worrying about being apart from her parents to the extent that it interferes with her academic or social life.

question_text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 2-year history of behavioral problems. She has temper outbursts six to seven times per week, which last anywhere between five minutes and half an hour. According to her father, she screams at others and throws things in anger “when things don't go her way”. He says that she is constantly irritable between outbursts. She has been suspended from school three times in the past year for physical aggression toward her classmates, but her grades have remained unaffected. She appears agitated and restless. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is uncooperative and refuses to answer questions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 2-year history of behavioral problems. She has temper outbursts six to seven times per week, which last anywhere between five minutes and half an hour. According to her father, she screams at others and throws things in anger “when things don't go her way”. He says that she is constantly irritable between outbursts. She has been suspended from school three times in the past year for physical aggression toward her classmates, but her grades have remained unaffected. She appears agitated and restless. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is uncooperative and refuses to answer questions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This child presents with severe and explosive temper outbursts, which have been present for > 12 months and are causing impairment at home and school.
learning_objective: Recognize disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD).

answers.explanation_why: The symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) can begin before the age of 12 years. However, ADHD does not result in temper tantrums, physical aggression, or pervasive irritability. Instead, patients with ADHD have features of hyperactivity (e.g., difficulty remaining seated, talking excessively) and/or a decline in academic performance due to inattention (e.g., failure to complete activities that require sustained effort, increased frequency of careless mistakes).

Children with bipolar disorder may be irritable and have recurrent incidents of physical and/or verbal aggression. However, the irritability would be episodic (due to a manic/hypomanic episode) unlike this child with chronic, pervasive irritability, and the incidents of physical or verbal aggression would be clustered around these episodes of irritability. Moreover, the episodes of irritability would be accompanied by a change in behavior and/or cognition (e.g., increased distractibility, grandiosity).

Patients with a conduct disorder may have a history of recurrent temper tantrums, episodes of physical aggression, and suspension from school. However, the episodes of verbal or physical aggression in a conduct disorder are usually premeditated unlike the impulsive aggression in this child. Moreover, the patient's mood would not be persistently negative (irritable, angry) in between the episodes of verbal or physical aggression, and a history of deceitfulness, aggression toward people or animals, and/or theft would also be present.

This patient's recurrent outbursts of anger (temper tantrums, physical aggression toward others) that occur in ≥ 2 settings (with parents and with peers) ≥ 3 times per week and chronic irritability between outbursts for ≥ 12 months are consistent with disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD). The onset of symptoms usually occurs before the age of 10 years. Individuals with DMDD are at an increased risk of developing major depressive disorder or anxiety disorders in adulthood.

Patients with an oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) would have temper tantrums and pervasive irritability, as well a history of symptoms in more than one setting (e.g., home and school). However, physical aggression is usually not seen in ODD. Moreover, a diagnosis of ODD cannot be made when the diagnostic criteria for a certain mood disorder are met.

Intermittent explosive disorder would present with recurrent temper tantrums and/or episodes of physical aggression that begin after the age of 6 years. However, the patient's mood would not be persistently negative (irritable, angry) in between the episodes of verbal or physical aggression.

question_text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of multiple behavioral problems. The parents report that their son has been bullying several classmates at school over the past year. During this period, he has been accused twice of stealing items from a local store. He has also beaten up the neighbor's son for no obvious reason. The parents state that they had to give up their dog for adoption after finding out that their son was torturing him. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He attends a local middle school and his performance at school is poor compared to his classmates. He often forgets to do his homework and argues with his teachers. He was also caught smoking cigarettes. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. He has poor attention and does not answer some of the questions. For questions he answers affirmatively about his actions, he sometimes replies, “So what?” Which of the following conditions is this patient most likely to develop?

The parents report that their son has been bullying several classmates at school over the past year. During this period, he has been accused twice of stealing items from a local store. He has also beaten up the neighbor's son for no obvious reason. The parents state that they had to give up their dog for adoption after finding out that their son was torturing him. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He attends a local middle school and his performance at school is poor compared to his classmates. He often forgets to do his homework and argues with his teachers. He was also caught smoking cigarettes. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. He has poor attention and does not answer some of the questions. For questions he answers affirmatively about his actions, he sometimes replies, “So what?” Which of the following conditions is this patient most likely to develop?
hint: This patient presents with antisocial and aggressive behavioral patterns that violate the basic rights of others and socially accepted, age-appropriate norms, which is suggestive of conduct disorder (CD).
learning_objective: Recognize the risk of antisocial personality disorder in patients with conduct disorder.

answers.explanation_why: The prevalence of comorbid depression in individuals with CD is less than 50%. Another condition that shares features with CD is more likely to develop in this patient.
CD is not known to be associated with an increased risk of obsessive-compulsive disorder.
The prevalence of a comorbid anxiety disorder in individuals with CD is less than 50%. Another condition that shares features with CD is more likely to develop in this patient.
Although this patient's condition increases his risk of developing bipolar disorder, he is more likely to develop another condition that shares features with CD.

Up to 70% of individuals with CD will eventually develop antisocial personality disorder (ASPD). The criteria for a CD must be met before the age of 15 years for a patient to be diagnosed with ASPD during adulthood. Both ASPD and CD have similar features such as deceitfulness, aggressiveness, and a failure to accept the rights of others or to conform to societal norms. The risk of ASPD is greater with childhood-onset CD when compared with onset during adolescence. Other conditions that are strongly associated with CD include ADHD and substance abuse.

Risk factors for early-onset dementia include Down syndrome, diabetes mellitus, atherosclerosis, hypertension, and/or a family history of Alzheimer disease. CD is not associated with an increased risk of dementia.

question_text: A previously healthy 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a change in behavior. The mother reports that over the past 6 months, her daughter has had frequent mood swings. Sometimes, she is irritable for several days and loses her temper easily. In between these episodes, she behaves normally, spends time with her friends, and participates in gymnastics training twice a week. Her mother has also noticed that her daughter needs more time than usual to get ready for school. Sometimes, she puts on an excessive amount of make-up. One month ago, her teacher informed the parents that their daughter had skipped school and was seen at the local mall with one of her classmates instead. The patient reports that she often feels tired, especially when she has to wake up early for school. On the weekends, she sleeps until 1 pm. Menses have occurred at 15- to 45-day intervals since menarche at the age of 12 years; they are not associated with abdominal discomfort or functional impairment. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient's behavior?
content_preview: A previously healthy 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a change in behavior. The mother reports that over the past 6 months, her daughter has had frequent mood swings. Sometimes, she is irritable for several days and loses her temper easily. In between these episodes, she behaves normally, spends time with her friends, and participates in gymnastics training twice a week. Her mother has also noticed that her daughter needs more time than usual to get ready for school. Sometimes, she puts on an excessive amount of make-up. One month ago, her teacher informed the parents that their daughter had skipped school and was seen at the local mall with one of her classmates instead. The patient reports that she often feels tired, especially when she has to wake up early for school. On the weekends, she sleeps until 1 pm. Menses have occurred at 15- to 45-day intervals since menarche at the age of 12 years; they are not associated with abdominal discomfort or functional impairment. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient's behavior?
hint: The patient's age and lack of functional impairment are important points worth noting.
learning_objective: Recognize normal adolescent behavior.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with borderline personality disorder can present with affective instability due to a marked reactivity of mood (e.g., intense episodic irritability usually lasting a few hours–days). However, affected individuals tend to have unstable relationships, display impulsivity, and recurrent suicidal gestures or self-mutilating behavior, all of which are inconsistent with this adolescent girl's presentation. Moreover, borderline personality disorder typically begins in early adulthood, not adolescence.

Puberty is accompanied by several cognitive, physical, and psychosocial changes. In the early stages of adolescence (onset of puberty 9–14 years in boys and 8–13 years in girls), individuals can experience negative feelings about their self-image, largely due to changes in their bodies and/or social pressure. Irritability (e.g., losing one's temper), mood swings, hypersomnia, fatigue, and infrequently skipping school, all of which are seen in this 13-year-old adolescent, are considered normal as long as they do not cause significant distress or functional impairment.

Patients with oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) can also present with irritable mood and loss of temper. However, the irritability associated with ODD is typically chronic (nonepisodic) and affected individuals often show argumentative, vindictive, and defiant behavior towards authority figures such as parents or teachers.

Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD) can manifest with mood swings, irritability, and loss of temper. Symptoms of DMDD are much more severe than the symptoms in this patient, must begin before the age of 10 years, and include extreme irritability, anger, and severe recurrent outbursts of temper for ≥ 12 months without interruption > 3 months. All of these criteria are absent in this patient.

Pediatric patients with major depressive disorder (MDD) may also present with fatigue, hypersomnia, and irritability. In children, classic symptoms of MDD (e.g., depressed mood, loss of energy) may be less marked but the diagnosis of MDD requires that symptoms be present for at least two consecutive weeks, whereas this adolescent girl's behavior is episodic. She also behaves normally, is active and social, all of which are atypical for MDD.

Premenstrual syndrome can manifest with irritability, fatigue, and mood swings. However, these symptoms typically only occur before menstruation. According to the DSM-V, symptoms must have been present in most menstrual cycles of the previous year and must be associated with significant distress or interference with usual activities (e.g., work, school, social life). This adolescent girl does not demonstrate symptoms that meet the criteria for premenstrual syndrome.

Bipolar disorder in adolescent patients often manifests with irritability, and ongoing fluctuating mixed and depressive symptoms, which shift rapidly over hours or even minutes. However, this patient is missing further symptoms of hypomania or mania, such as euphoria, grandiose ideation, rapid, disorganized thinking and speech, and risky behavior.

Body dysmorphic disorder often includes camouflaging of disliked body parts. However, it typically also involves a preoccupation with a specific aspect of one's physical appearance, self-injurious behavior, and social withdrawal, all of which are not present in this patient.
