question_text: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for a well-child visit. The parents report that she has been crying excessively since the last visit and are concerned that she is not well. Their babysitter has told them that she does not stop crying even with feeding or burping. They say that she used to be calm when she was left alone, but over the past week, she starts to cry whenever they leave the room. She was exclusively breastfed until 6 months of age. Her parents have gradually introduced semisolid foods over the past three months. She is at the 75^th percentile for height and weight. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, she turns her head when her name is called. She coos “ma” and “da.” She crawls on the examination table, is able to independently get into a seated position, and passes a teddy from one hand to the other. She can be pulled up to stand but cannot stand without support. Plantar reflex is present bilaterally. The anterior fontanelle is soft. She begins to cry when the physician picks her up. The remainder of the examination does not show any abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for a well-child visit. The parents report that she has been crying excessively since the last visit and are concerned that she is not well. Their babysitter has told them that she does not stop crying even with feeding or burping. They say that she used to be calm when she was left alone, but over the past week, she starts to cry whenever they leave the room. She was exclusively breastfed until 6 months of age. Her parents have gradually introduced semisolid foods over the past three months. She is at the 75th percentile for height and weight. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, she turns her head when her name is called. She coos “ma” and “da.” She crawls on the examination table, is able to independently get into a seated position, and passes a teddy from one hand to the other. She can be pulled up to stand but cannot stand without support. Plantar reflex is present bilaterally. The anterior fontanelle is soft. She begins to cry when the physician picks her up. The remainder of the examination does not show any abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This 9-month old child presents with the appropriate gross motor skills (able to independently get into a seated position), fine motor skills (transfers objects from one hand to the other), and language milestones (cooing “ma” and “da”) for her age. Plantar reflex usually disappears around 12 months of age.
learning_objective: Recognize normal behavior in a 9-month-old child.

answers.explanation_why: Separation anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive anxiety of separation from major attachment figures such as the parents and usually develops during childhood. Although this infant presents with symptoms of separation anxiety (e.g., starts to cry when her parents leave the room), the diagnosis of separation anxiety disorder cannot be established at this age.

Reactive attachment disorder manifests with an inhibited, emotionally withdrawn behavior towards caretakers without seeking comfort when distressed. This patient, however, cries when her parents leave the room, indicating a strong attachment and anxiety of separation of attachment figures, which is not consistent with reactive attachment disorder.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) usually manifests with detachment and inability or difficulty to form relationships. This patient, however, cries when her parents leave the room, indicating a strong attachment and anxiety of separation of attachment figures. Moreover, patients with ASD typically present with other findings such as abnormal language development and stereotypical patterns of behavior (e.g., hand flapping, adverse response to sounds), none of which is seen here.

Infantile colic manifests with episodes of crying in otherwise healthy and thriving infants, which is seen here. However, crying in infantile colic is not associated with the absence of attachment figures, or the presence of strangers. Moreover, infantile colic typically resolves spontaneously by 3–4 months of age.

This 9-month-old child presents with milestones that are appropriate for her age. Her crying pattern is consistent with stranger anxiety (crying when picked up by strangers) and separation anxiety (crying when her parents leave the room), both of which are typical and normal social behaviors in children of this age. See “Developmental milestones in infants” table.

This infant shows no signs or symptoms suggestive of physical child abuse (e.g., injuries at different stages of healing). Infants who are subject to sexual child abuse may present with normal physical examination findings or with findings restricted to genital and anal areas, which can easily be overseen. Sexual child abuse should be considered in children with recurrent urinary tract infections and behavioral changes. This patient's presentation, however, is not suggestive of sexual child abuse or other types of child abuse (e.g., child neglect).

question_text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 2-year history of poor performance in school. Her parents report that her teachers are surprised by her academic underperformance because they find her to be “a bright and vivacious student.” Her academic performance has not improved despite extra tutoring at home. Her parents have noticed that she often does not understand what she reads. She has attended elementary school since the age of 6 years and her parents are native English speakers. She has no history of serious illness and receives no medications. She appears well. She is at the 75^th percentile for height and weight. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, mood and affect are cheerful and her thought content is normal. Her speech is intelligible and fluent. When asked to read from a children's novel, she reads certain words slowly and often mispronounces them. Motor skills and cognitive abilities are appropriate for age. Visual acuity testing shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 2-year history of poor performance in school. Her parents report that her teachers are surprised by her academic underperformance because they find her to be “a bright and vivacious student.” Her academic performance has not improved despite extra tutoring at home. Her parents have noticed that she often does not understand what she reads. She has attended elementary school since the age of 6 years and her parents are native English speakers. She has no history of serious illness and receives no medications. She appears well. She is at the 75th percentile for height and weight. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, mood and affect are cheerful and her thought content is normal. Her speech is intelligible and fluent. When asked to read from a children's novel, she reads certain words slowly and often mispronounces them. Motor skills and cognitive abilities are appropriate for age. Visual acuity testing shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Children with persistent impairment in mathematics (dyscalculia) or writing (e.g., spelling, grammar, or punctuation) would also receive this diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize specific learning disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Intellectual developmental disorder manifests with poor academic performance during childhood. However, this condition typically also causes more generalized impairments in cognitive function (e.g., in learning, abstract thinking, and reasoning) and adaptive function (e.g., in social interaction and daily activities), which are not seen here. In contrast, this patient only has difficulty reading and is otherwise described as a bright student.

Childhood-onset fluency disorder is characterized by disturbances in the normal fluency of speech, which can result in poor academic performance during childhood. Although this patient has difficulty with reading, her speech is intelligible and fluent.

This patient's history of difficulty reading, which has persisted for ≥ 6 months in the absence of intellectual disabilities or other disorders that could better explain this difficulty, is characteristic of dyslexia, a type of specific learning disorder. These conditions typically develop during early school years and can result in poor academic performance, as seen in this patient. General functioning and intelligence are usually normal. Learning difficulties vary in severity but usually persist into adulthood. Management of specific learning disorders includes academic support, psychotherapy, and extracurricular activities to improve academic and social inclusion.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) can result in poor academic performance during childhood. However, this condition is also characterized by impairment in social interaction and communication as well as stereotyped patterns of behavior, interests, and activities, none of which are seen here. In addition, patients with ASD often have language impairment; this patient's speech is fluent and intelligible. Moreover, symptoms of ASD are typically evident before 2–3 years of age.

Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) can result in poor academic performance during childhood. However, this condition also typically manifests with symptoms of inattention (e.g., poor attention to detail, difficulty sustaining attention during tasks) and hyperactivity (e.g., restlessness, excessive talking, fidgeting), none of which are seen in this patient.

Normal variations in academic attainment include difficulty reading and poor academic performance during childhood. However, variations in academic attainment are usually associated with external factors, such as poor instruction or learning in a second language. In contrast, this patient's parents are native English speakers and her learning difficulties persist despite adequate educational opportunities (e.g., extra tutoring).

question_text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because they are worried about his behavior. For the past year, he has been setting mail boxes on fire in their neighborhood. Three months ago, he brought a box of matches to school and threatened to burn down a classroom. His father says, “We've tried everything, but he won't listen to us anymore. The last straw was when he broke into someone's car yesterday and stole a laptop!” The patient has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His older brother has bipolar disorder. The patient does not smoke cigarettes. He drinks one to three beers on weekends. He has experimented with cocaine but has never used intravenous drugs. On mental status examination, he has an angry mood and anxious affect. He is fully oriented. He does not have hallucinations or delusions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because they are worried about his behavior. For the past year, he has been setting mail boxes on fire in their neighborhood. Three months ago, he brought a box of matches to school and threatened to burn down a classroom. His father says, “We've tried everything, but he won't listen to us anymore. The last straw was when he broke into someone's car yesterday and stole a laptop!” The patient has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His older brother has bipolar disorder. The patient does not smoke cigarettes. He drinks one to three beers on weekends. He has experimented with cocaine but has never used intravenous drugs. On mental status examination, he has an angry mood and anxious affect. He is fully oriented. He does not have hallucinations or delusions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with criminal behavior and aggressiveness towards others for the past 12 months. His condition is more common among boys and frequently manifests in association with additional behavioral conditions.
learning_objective: Recognize conduct disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD) can manifest with anger and recurrent aggressive outbursts over a period of ≥ 12 months in an individual between the age of 6–18 years, as seen here. However, DMDD is not associated with violation of the rights of others (e.g., theft, destruction of property). Additionally, DMDD is usually associated with trouble functioning due to persistent irritability between episodes of aggression, which is not the case in this patient. Moreover, individuals with DMDD typically develop disruptive behavior before 10 years of age, whereas this patient's behavior began at 15 years of age.

Pyromania is characterized by intentional fire setting, as seen here. However, pyromania is not associated with anger, aggressiveness, stealing, or defiant behavior. Moreover, individuals with pyromania cannot control the impulse to set fire and experience internal tension before, and relief after, starting or witnessing a fire, none of which has been reported in this case. This patient's history is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

The diagnostic criteria for conduct disorder (CD) include aggression (e.g., arguing with parents, threatening others) and certain criminal behaviors (e.g., destruction of property and theft) with severe rule violations, all of which are seen in this case. To confirm a diagnosis of CD, the disturbance in behavior must persist for ≥ 12 months and significantly impair social, academic, or occupational functioning. CD typically manifests during childhood or adolescence and may be preceded by oppositional defiant disorder. Individuals with CD are at risk for developing antisocial personality disorder (ASPD) and should be assessed for ASPD when they reach 18 years of age.

Risk factors for developing CD include genetic (e.g., positive family history), psychological (e.g., child neglect), environmental (e.g., exposure to toxins), and social factors (e.g., family instability). The first-line treatment for CD involves psychotherapy (e.g., cognitive behavioral therapy, parental training). Patients with severe aggression might also require pharmacotherapy (e.g., risperidone).

images.title: Symptom-duration criteria for diagnosis of psychiatric disorders with childhood onset

answers.explanation_why: The recreational use of certain drugs, such as cocaine, may lead to aggression and impaired judgment. Criminal behavior such as theft is also often associated with substance use disorder (SUD). Although this patient's condition is associated with an increased risk of SUD, his personal history and substance use history are not consistent with features of SUD such as impaired control (e.g., intense desire to obtain and use alcohol or cocaine, heavy alcohol or cocaine use), risky use (e.g., driving under the influence), or social and functional impairment from drug use (e.g., truancy due to spending a great deal of time buying, using, recovering from alcohol or cocaine).

Intermittent explosive disorder (IED) most commonly occurs in individuals 14–17 years of age and can manifest with outbursts of aggression and property destruction, as seen in this case. However, the episodes of aggression in IED are usually triggered by an identifiable stressor, which is not reported here, and IED is not associated with theft. Moreover, IED usually causes the affected individual significant distress, while this patient shows no feelings of remorse, regret, or embarrassment following his outbursts.

Oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) is characterized by anger and defiant behavior towards authority figures (e.g., parents) that lasts ≥ 6 months, all of which is seen in this patient. However, this patient also shows behavior that violates the rights of others (e.g., stealing, destruction of property), which is not a feature of ODD. Moreover, individuals with ODD tend to argue with authority figures and deliberately annoy others, neither of which are prominent features in this patient.

question_text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because he has had difficulty following the rules in his kindergarten class. His parents report that he avoids situations in which he has to take part in a conversation and becomes frustrated when he is not understood. According to his teacher, he often disregards instructions and cannot complete his assignments without visual cues. He does not have many friends but enjoys playing with one other child. The patient was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. He did not use any word combinations until 28 months of age and has been using descriptive words incorrectly since he started speaking. He appears well. He is at the 35^th percentile for height and 47^th percentile for weight. His vital signs are within normal limits. During examination, he undresses and dresses himself independently and draws a person with a head, body, arms, and legs. He can count to ten. His speech is 100% intelligible but his vocabulary is restricted for his age. He pronounces single words clearly and speaks in sentences of 2–3 words without interruptions. Audiometry and visual acuity test show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because he has had difficulty following the rules in his kindergarten class. His parents report that he avoids situations in which he has to take part in a conversation and becomes frustrated when he is not understood. According to his teacher, he often disregards instructions and cannot complete his assignments without visual cues. He does not have many friends but enjoys playing with one other child. The patient was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. He did not use any word combinations until 28 months of age and has been using descriptive words incorrectly since he started speaking. He appears well. He is at the 35th percentile for height and 47th percentile for weight. His vital signs are within normal limits. During examination, he undresses and dresses himself independently and draws a person with a head, body, arms, and legs. He can count to ten. His speech is 100% intelligible but his vocabulary is restricted for his age. He pronounces single words clearly and speaks in sentences of 2–3 words without interruptions. Audiometry and visual acuity test show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Instead of saying “I went to the park and ate ice cream,” this patient might say “I go park. I eat ice.”
learning_objective: Recognize a language disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Selective mutism is a childhood anxiety disorder that is characterized by the refusal to speak in certain situations (e.g., at school or the doctor's office) while readily speaking in others (e.g., with family or friends). This patient shows a general reluctance to engage in conversations that is not specific to the situation. Furthermore, incorrect use of descriptive words and the formation of short sentences with limited vocabulary indicate a different type of disorder.

Intellectual disability can result in communication difficulties but also affects other aspects of social and cognitive development. This 5-year-old patient shows age-appropriate social and cognitive functioning (e.g., he counts to ten, draws a person with a head, body, arms, and legs, has a friend he plays with, can dress himself) and only has difficulty with speech.

Speech sound disorder (SSD), which is characterized by difficulties in sound articulation, can result in irritability and frustration and a reluctance to engage in conversations. However, patients with SSD are able to follow instructions without visual cues. Patients with SSD also have partially or completely unintelligible speech because they add or delete certain sounds or syllables from a word and substitute or distort one or more sounds (e.g., “I wend to the dark, and I ate ith eam” instead of “I went to the park, and I ate ice cream.").

Language disorder (LD) usually develops in early childhood. Its key features are reduced vocabulary for age, incorrect understanding of a word's meaning, limited ability to string words together to form complete sentences, and/or incorrect grammar use. These features impair the patient's ability to speak and write (expressive LD) as well as understand (receptive LD), which leads to irritability and frustration, reluctance to engage in conversations, inability to follow instructions without visual cues, and, eventually, difficulties in social participation and academic performance. The diagnosis is typically confirmed after the age of 4 years, at which point children should have a vocabulary of approx. 1500 words, be able to form 4–5 word sentences, and use certain grammatical structures (e.g., prepositions, conjunctions, tense) correctly. In patients with language disorder, speech fluency is unaffected and speech remains intelligible. Other aspects of social and cognitive development are not delayed (e.g., dressing oneself, counting to ten, drawing a person with a head, body, arms, and legs by the age of 5 years).

If a caregiver, parent, or teacher has any concerns about a child's speech or language development, the child should be evaluated for developmental communication disorders (e.g., language disorder, speech sound disorder, childhood-onset fluency disorder, pragmatic communication disorder), specific learning disorders (e.g., dyslexia), autism-spectrum disorders, intellectual disability, and hearing impairment. Treatment of communication disorders consists of speech and language therapy.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) can cause impairments in social interaction and communication, and the disorder is often associated with language deficits. However, patients with ASD also have stereotyped and restricted patterns of behavior and interests by the age of 2–3 years and have difficulty engaging in nonverbal communication (e.g., maintaining eye contact, understanding social cues). In addition, this patient shows social-emotional reciprocity, a feature often absent in patients with ASD, when he enjoys playing with another child or becomes frustrated in response to not being understood.

Childhood-onset fluency disorder (stuttering), which is characterized by disruptions in speech fluency, can result in irritability and frustration and a reluctance to engage in conversations despite having intelligible speech. However, fluency disorder does not result in impaired vocabulary or an inability to follow instructions without visual cues; it is instead characterized by repetition or prolongation of sounds, syllables, or words, and repeated interruptions when speaking (e.g., “"I went tt tt….. to the park, and and ……. I ate ice cr cr ream” instead of “I went to the park, and I ate ice cream.").

question_text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician for an adolescent wellness examination. She feels well. She plays on her high school's softball team, performs well in school, and gets along with her friends and family. Medical history is unremarkable, and the patient takes no medications. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She is not sexually active. Vaccinations are up-to-date. Growth and development are appropriate for age. Vital signs are within normal limits. During physical examination, the physician notices a 1-cm sized hypopigmented macule on the dorsal surface of the left forearm. When the physician inquires about the lesion, the patient says that she burnt herself using a friend's cigarette butt 2 months ago. She says that she does not know why she did it and that her parents do not know about the lesion because she has been covering it with long-sleeved clothing. She says that she has not harmed herself before this incident or since then. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation, hallucinations, or delusions. Her thought process and speech are organized. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient asks the physician not to tell her parents about the skin lesion. In addition to exploring the reasons for the patient's request, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician for an adolescent wellness examination. She feels well. She plays on her high school's softball team, performs well in school, and gets along with her friends and family. Medical history is unremarkable, and the patient takes no medications. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She is not sexually active. Vaccinations are up-to-date. Growth and development are appropriate for age. Vital signs are within normal limits. During physical examination, the physician notices a 1-cm sized hypopigmented macule on the dorsal surface of the left forearm. When the physician inquires about the lesion, the patient says that she burnt herself using a friend's cigarette butt 2 months ago. She says that she does not know why she did it and that her parents do not know about the lesion because she has been covering it with long-sleeved clothing. She says that she has not harmed herself before this incident or since then. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation, hallucinations, or delusions. Her thought process and speech are organized. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient asks the physician not to tell her parents about the skin lesion. In addition to exploring the reasons for the patient's request, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Nonsuicidal self-injury (NSSI) is defined as intentional self-injury to the surface of the body (e.g., cutting, burning, scratching) without suicidal intent and is commonly seen in adolescents. The severity and frequency of the self-injury and the presence or absence of suicidal ideation or other psychiatric comorbidities determine how NSSI is managed.
learning_objective: Recognize the importance of respecting adolescent patient confidentiality and provide appropriate anticipatory guidance.

answers.content: Inform the patient that this information needs to be disclosed to her parents
answers.explanation_why: If information about a patient who is an adolescent has to be disclosed to their parents, this should be reviewed and discussed openly with the patient beforehand. In the case of NSSI in an adolescent, the physician can respect the patient's wish to refrain from disclosure to the parents if there is no reinforced behavioral pattern (e.g., a single episode that was not done to cope with distress), the injury is nonsevere, and there is no suicidal ideation, psychiatric comorbidity, or functional impairment.

answers.content: Respect the patient's wishes and provide anticipatory guidance
answers.explanation_why: Psychotherapy for NSSI (e.g., dialectical behavioral therapy) is not required unless there are recurring episodes of NSSI, if the NSSI was performed to cope with distress, and/or if the NSSI was severe enough to warrant medical attention. Disclosing NSSI to the patient's parents depends upon the physician's judgment but is usually not needed if there is no reinforced behavioral pattern, the injury is nonsevere, and there is no suicidal ideation, psychiatric comorbidity, or functional impairment. Regardless of the presence or absence of NSSI, anticipatory guidance should be provided at every adolescent wellness examination; for adolescents aged 15–17 years, topics of discussion during anticipatory guidance include emotional well-being, coping with stress, living situation, relationship with the family, school performance, substance use, sexual activity, and personal safety.

answers.content: Admit the patient to the hospital for further evaluation
answers.explanation_why: Hospitalization should be considered if the NSSI requires medical attention (e.g., continuous bleeding) or if the patient has suicidal ideation or symptoms of agitation, aggression, or psychosis (e.g., hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thought and speech process) that cause them to pose harm to themself or others. This patient has had one episode of NSSI without suicidal ideation or severe injury, so hospitalization is not indicated at this point.

answers.content: Recommend sessions of dialectical behavioral therapy
answers.explanation_why: Dialectical behavioral therapy (DBT) is one of the first-line treatments of NSSI and is performed to prevent or correct reinforced behavior but is only indicated if there are recurring episodes of NSSI, if the NSSI was performed to cope with distress, and/or if the NSSI was severe enough to warrant medical attention. At this time, DBT is not indicated for this patient.

question_text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a well-child examination. She reports that for almost a year, he has been episodically “acting out” by stomping his feet and screaming at home. She says that she sometimes scolds him during these episodes in an attempt to correct his behavior, but his tantrums have become worse and more frequent over time. According to his teachers at preschool, he is calm and plays cooperatively. He was born at term and has been healthy since. He can draw a square, hop on one foot, and brush his teeth. He can identify several colors and numbers and occasionally tells stories to his parents. He enjoys being read stories before bedtime, and he sleeps 11 hours every night and 1–2 hours during the day. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 40^th percentile for both height and weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The mother is worried that his behavior will continue when he starts kindergarten next year and asks if it would be appropriate to gently spank her son to discipline him. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for responding to the boy’s behavior?
content_preview: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a well-child examination. She reports that for almost a year, he has been episodically “acting out” by stomping his feet and screaming at home. She says that she sometimes scolds him during these episodes in an attempt to correct his behavior, but his tantrums have become worse and more frequent over time. According to his teachers at preschool, he is calm and plays cooperatively. He was born at term and has been healthy since. He can draw a square, hop on one foot, and brush his teeth. He can identify several colors and numbers and occasionally tells stories to his parents. He enjoys being read stories before bedtime, and he sleeps 11 hours every night and 1–2 hours during the day. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 40th percentile for both height and weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The mother is worried that his behavior will continue when he starts kindergarten next year and asks if it would be appropriate to gently spank her son to discipline him. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for responding to the boy’s behavior?
hint: This child's behavior is consistent with temper tantrums, which are a common and developmentally normal behavior in children 2–5 years of age. Parents must respond to temper tantrums with age-appropriate measures.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate response to preschoolers' temper tantrums.

answers.content: Take away the child's favorite toy after he has a tantrum
answers.explanation_why: Taking away the child's favorite toy after he has a tantrum is an example of negative punishment. Although punishment may be effective in older children and adolescents when coupled with rewards for good behavior, it is not effective for decreasing unwanted behavior in preschoolers. Moreover, while punishment may result in a temporary decrease in unwanted behavior, it does not typically lead to behavior extinction.

answers.content: Restrict the child's daytime naps and put him to bed earlier in the evening
answers.explanation_why: Children who get insufficient sleep can become cranky, which can contribute to temper tantrums. This child is getting sufficient sleep for his age (10–13 hours per day including naps). Furthermore, daytime napping is normal until 5–6 years of age and should not be restricted.

answers.content: Ignore the child while he is having a tantrum
answers.explanation_why:
Ignoring the child (e.g., by putting them on time-out) is one of the most effective approaches for a preschooler who is having a temper tantrum. Although ignoring the child may initially result in a temporary increase in the behavior, this approach eventually leads to extinction by eliminating any positive reinforcement of the behavior. If using a time-out, the parent should briefly explain to the child that the time-out is related to their temper tantrum. No other communication (e.g., scolding, teaching) should take place during a time-out. Physical punishment is largely ineffective and strongly discouraged because it can cause physical harm. Some forms of physical punishment are considered child abuse under state and federal laws. Physical punishment can also have deleterious effects on the child's psychosocial development, e.g., by teaching them that violence is an appropriate means of conflict resolution.

While this is a developmentally normal behavior in preschoolers, health care providers should evaluate children with temper tantrums for conditions that can cause or contribute to tantrums (e.g., hearing and/or visual impairment, learning disabilities).

answers.content: Explain to the child why his behavior is socially inappropriate
answers.explanation_why: Explaining to the child why his behavior is socially inappropriate is useful in older children and adolescents. However, this technique has limited effectiveness in preschoolers. Explaining to a preschooler why a behavior is inappropriate may actually reinforce the behavior by giving them attention.

answers.content: Offering the boy chocolate during a tantrum
answers.explanation_why: Offering the child chocolate during a tantrum is an example of positive reinforcement. Although this response might temporarily console the child, it is likely to inadvertently cause an increase in the unwanted behavior in the future. Parents should reward good behavior rather than reinforce unwanted behavior.

question_text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-month history of bedwetting about 2–3 times per week. He previously went 1 year without wetting the bed. The mother reports that she and her husband have been monitoring their son's voiding habits over the past month. He passes stool of normal color and consistency approximately once daily and voids his bladder 5–7 times per day. He drinks little during dinner and before going to bed. They have not noticed any urgency, hesitancy, straining, postmicturition dribble, or episodes of urinary incontinence during the day. The patient says that he has no pain in his abdominal or genital region prior to, during, or after voiding. He recently started primary school and says he enjoys it. He is able to balance and hop on one foot, tie a knot, name 6 colors, and dress with minimal assistance from his parents. He is at the 50^th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-month history of bedwetting about 2–3 times per week. He previously went 1 year without wetting the bed. The mother reports that she and her husband have been monitoring their son's voiding habits over the past month. He passes stool of normal color and consistency approximately once daily and voids his bladder 5–7 times per day. He drinks little during dinner and before going to bed. They have not noticed any urgency, hesitancy, straining, postmicturition dribble, or episodes of urinary incontinence during the day. The patient says that he has no pain in his abdominal or genital region prior to, during, or after voiding. He recently started primary school and says he enjoys it. He is able to balance and hop on one foot, tie a knot, name 6 colors, and dress with minimal assistance from his parents. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: A child who previously achieved nocturnal continence and has begun to wet the bed again has secondary enuresis.
learning_objective: Recognize secondary enuresis, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Desmopressin therapy is indicated for patients ≥ 7 years of age with nocturnal enuresis if nonpharmacological measures (e.g., fluid restriction at night, timed voiding, enuresis alarm) are unsuccessful or if more rapid improvement is desired. However, organic causes of secondary enuresis should be ruled out before initiating treatment.

Urological imaging (e.g., a voiding cystourethrogram) is used to diagnose urinary tract abnormalities in patients with secondary enuresis who have findings such as symptoms of urinary tract obstruction, a history of multiple urinary tract infections, and significant urinary symptoms during the daytime. This patient has no such findings that suggest urinary tract abnormalities.

Urinalysis is indicated in all patients with nocturnal enuresis to exclude organic causes, such as occult urinary tract infection, diabetic ketoacidosis, and diabetes insipidus. In addition to urinalysis, a detailed history, a voiding diary, and a physical examination should be completed prior to initiating treatment. Secondary enuresis is typically caused by an underlying condition (e.g., constipation, obstructive sleep apnea, urinary tract abnormalities, certain psychiatric disorders) or new psychosocial stressors (e.g., starting primary school). Treatment includes nonpharmacological measures (e.g., fluid restriction at night, psychoeducation, timed voiding), training with an enuresis alarm, pharmacotherapy (e.g., desmopressin), and management of any underlying conditions (e.g., antibiotics for urinary tract infection).

Enuresis alarms are a first-line therapy for patients < 7 years of age with nocturnal enuresis who do not respond to behavioral modifications (e.g., timed voiding, fluid restriction at night, psychoeducation). However, this patient is 7 years old, and organic causes of secondary enuresis should be ruled out before initiating treatment.

Reassurance and follow-up are appropriate for children < 5 years because bedwetting is normal for this age. This patient is 7 years old and presents with secondary enuresis, which warrants another step in management.

question_text:
A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 7-week history of abnormal dietary behavior. The patient has been eating scraps of paper that she finds around the house and constantly asks her parents for ice to eat. The family relocated because of her dad's job and the patient started kindergarten 2 months ago. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears well. She is at the 55^th percentile for height and the 50^th percentile for weight. Development is appropriate for age. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL

Serum

 Na^+

139 mEq/L

 K^+

4.1 mEq/L

 Ca^2+

8.8 mg/dL

 Aspartate aminotransferase
18 U/L

 Alanine aminotransferase
16 U/L

 Iron
88 μg/dL

 Ferritin
110 ng/mL

 Lead

3.7 μg/dL (N  < 3.5)

A peripheral blood smear shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 7-week history of abnormal dietary behavior. The patient has been eating scraps of paper that she finds around the house and constantly asks her parents for ice to eat. The family relocated because of her dad's job and the patient started kindergarten 2 months ago. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears well. She is at the 55th percentile for height and the 50th percentile for weight. Development is appropriate for age. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 13.1 g/dL Serum Na+ 139 mEq/L K+ 4.1 mEq/L Ca2+ 8.8 mg/dL Aspartate aminotransferase 18 U/L Alanine aminotransferase 16 U/L Iron 88 μg/dL Ferritin 110 ng/mL Lead 3.7 μg/dL (N < 3.5) A peripheral blood smear shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's history of eating paper and ice in addition to her recent stressors (moving and starting kindergarten) is highly suggestive of pica syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize pica syndrome, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, such as fluoxetine, can be used in patients with pica refractory to first-line therapy. However, this patient has not yet received the first-line treatment.

The DSM-5 defines pica as the consumption of nonnutritive substances (e.g., dirt, ice, ash, paper, charcoal, chalk, cloth, baby powder) over a period of at least one month. Pica is associated with multiple risk factors including stress, nutritional deficiencies (e.g., iron), low socioeconomic status, mental health disorders, child neglect, and pregnancy. Behavioral therapy (e.g., differential reinforcement, cognitive behavioral therapy) is the treatment of choice. For patients with refractory symptoms, pharmacotherapy (e.g., SSRIs) may be considered. All patients with pica should be screened for iron deficiency and lead poisoning. Pica is a risk factor for lead poisoning. For patients with mildly elevated blood lead levels (i.e., < 45 μg/dL), addressing risk factors for lead poisoning (e.g., by treating pica) and limiting lead exposure by removing the source (e.g., paint, furniture, water, toys, soil, dust, secondhand exposure) suffices. Chelation therapy (e.g., with oral succimer) is only recommended in children with a blood lead level > 45 μg/dL.
Reassurance alone is not appropriate in patients with pica because there is an increased risk of morbidity and mortality secondary to bowel obstruction, bezoars, and toxicity.

Although iron deficiency is a risk factor for pica, iron supplementation (e.g., with oral ferrous sulfate) is not indicated if the patient does not have iron deficiency. This patient's normal serum iron and ferritin concentrations rule out an iron deficiency.

Chelation therapy with intramuscular dimercaprol is reserved for patients with blood lead levels ≥ 70 μg/dL or features of acute lead encephalopathy (e.g., altered mental status, vomiting, seizures). Chelation therapy can adversely affect growth rate and studies have shown that chelation therapy in children with mildly elevated BLL (i.e., < 45 μg/dL) is not associated with better neurodevelopmental outcomes when compared to patients who have not received chelation therapy.

question_text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because of excessive blinking and jumping and sudden, uncontrollable twisting of his body for the past 13 months. His symptoms worsen when he is tired or stressed. His teacher reports that he frequently uses obscene language in class and gets into fights with his friends because he insults their physical appearance. Growth and development are appropriate for age. His only medications are acetaminophen and metoclopramide, which he takes occasionally for fever or nausea. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows no abnormalities. During the examination, he says the physician is “stupid and ugly.” The patient frequently jumps and twists his body from side to side on examination. Excessive blinking occurs while at rest. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely clinical course of this patient’s condition?
content_preview: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because of excessive blinking and jumping and sudden, uncontrollable twisting of his body for the past 13 months. His symptoms worsen when he is tired or stressed. His teacher reports that he frequently uses obscene language in class and gets into fights with his friends because he insults their physical appearance. Growth and development are appropriate for age. His only medications are acetaminophen and metoclopramide, which he takes occasionally for fever or nausea. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows no abnormalities. During the examination, he says the physician is “stupid and ugly.” The patient frequently jumps and twists his body from side to side on examination. Excessive blinking occurs while at rest. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely clinical course of this patient’s condition?
hint: Multiple motor tics (jumping, twisting the body, blinking) along with a vocal tic (coprolalia) lasting for > 1 year in a child suggest Tourette syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Tourette syndrome, and recall its typical clinical course.

answers.content: Resolution of motor tics with continued vocal tics
answers.explanation_why: In Tourette syndrome, either motor or vocal tics can predominate, and tics may vary in anatomical location, frequency, number, complexity, type, and/or severity over time. However, resolution of motor tics with no improvement in vocal tics is not a typical pattern in Tourette syndrome.

Tourette syndrome manifests before 18 years of age, typically occurring between 4–6 years. The severity of tics usually peaks between 10–12 years of age. This condition typically improves during adolescence, and most affected individuals experience no tics or only mild tics by early adulthood.

Treatment consists of nonpharmacological interventions, such as comprehensive behavioral intervention for tics (CBIT) and habit reversal training. Pharmacotherapy with antidopaminergic drugs, alpha-adrenergic drugs, or neuroleptics is indicated if behavioral interventions are unsuccessful.

answers.content: Recurrence after initial resolution of symptoms
answers.explanation_why: Although tic disorders can resolve in puberty and recur in adulthood (adult-onset tics), this is not the most likely course of Tourette syndrome.

Gradual worsening of symptoms over time is typically seen in Huntington disease, which manifests with sudden, involuntary movements of the limbs, neck, head, and face. Common features of Huntington disease such as sensory deficits (e.g., clumsiness), dementia, and/or autonomic symptoms (e.g., hyperhidrosis, urinary incontinence) are not seen here. Additionally, Huntington disease occurs during adulthood (20–50 years of age) rather than childhood. Although symptoms of Tourette syndrome may worsen over time, another clinical course is more likely.

answers.content: Complete resolution of symptoms after discontinuation of medication
answers.explanation_why: Tardive dyskinesia due to dopamine antagonists (e.g., metoclopramide) can completely resolve with discontinuation. Although tardive dyskinesia can manifest with involuntary movements of the mouth, tongue, face, and limbs, vocal tics (e.g., coprolalia) are not expected.

question_text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-year history of poor performance at school. His mother says the patient has had difficulties with speech from an early age. He often refuses to wear shoes, repetitively flaps his hands, and is easily startled by certain sounds. She says his teacher reports that he mostly plays by himself, which consists of lining up toy trucks. Medical history is remarkable for functional constipation. His only medication is polyethylene glycol as needed. He is at the 60^th percentile for height, the 55^th percentile for weight, and the 88^th percentile for head circumference. He does not respond to the physician's questions but occasionally looks at the objects that the physician points to and uses physical gestures to show interest in objects. Hearing and vision tests show no abnormalities. Which of the following factors in this patient most strongly indicates a poor prognosis?
content_preview: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-year history of poor performance at school. His mother says the patient has had difficulties with speech from an early age. He often refuses to wear shoes, repetitively flaps his hands, and is easily startled by certain sounds. She says his teacher reports that he mostly plays by himself, which consists of lining up toy trucks. Medical history is remarkable for functional constipation. His only medication is polyethylene glycol as needed. He is at the 60th percentile for height, the 55th percentile for weight, and the 88th percentile for head circumference. He does not respond to the physician's questions but occasionally looks at the objects that the physician points to and uses physical gestures to show interest in objects. Hearing and vision tests show no abnormalities. Which of the following factors in this patient most strongly indicates a poor prognosis?
hint: Impairment in communication and social interaction (e.g., playing alone), restricted patterns of behavior (e.g., narrow interest in lining up toy trucks), and repetitive movements (e.g., hand flapping) are core features of autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
learning_objective: Recognize autism spectrum disorder, and recall its prognostic factors.

answers.explanation_why: Persistent speech impairment by the age of 5–6 years is a major indicator of poor prognosis in children with ASD. Early intervention by speech-language pathologists can promote the development of speech, language, and communication skills to improve overall patient outcomes. Other indicators of poor prognosis in ASD include cognitive impairment, persistent absence of joint attention, a history of seizures or neurological comorbidities, and late treatment initiation.

Hyperreactivity to sensory input is a feature of ASD and can result in behaviors such as avoiding certain clothing (e.g., due to an aversion to specific textures) and startling easily with certain sounds. However, sensory hyperreactivity does not significantly influence the prognosis of individuals with ASD.

Fixated interests, which result in stereotyped activities and behavior patterns, are a core feature of ASD. However, fixated interests can also manifest in mild ASD and do not significantly influence the prognosis.

Joint attention is the ability to intentionally focus on an object with another person by one alerting the other through actions like pointing or eye gazing. In a patient with ASD, the ability to engage in joint attention (e.g., looking at objects that the physician points to) indicates a good prognosis.

Children with ASD may be at higher risk of having difficulties with toilet training, often triggering constipation. However, functional constipation is a common condition in young children and does not significantly influence the prognosis of ASD.

question_text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother for a follow-up visit. Two months ago, the patient's father died in a motor vehicle accident. Since then, the mother reports that the child has been frequently saying "when daddy comes back" and has had an increase in defiant behavior, including two severe temper tantrums. The mother also notes that the child has become more clingy, insists on sleeping in her mother's bed, and requests to take her blanket everywhere. The mother is concerned about these changes and seeks guidance on how to best support her daughter. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
content_preview: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother for a follow-up visit. Two months ago, the patient's father died in a motor vehicle accident. Since then, the mother reports that the child has been frequently saying "when daddy comes back" and has had an increase in defiant behavior, including two severe temper tantrums. The mother also notes that the child has become more clingy, insists on sleeping in her mother's bed, and requests to take her blanket everywhere. The mother is concerned about these changes and seeks guidance on how to best support her daughter. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
learning_objective: Recognize the characteristics of developmentally appropriate grief in a young child.

answers.content: Encourage the mother to avoid confronting her daughter and to limit discussion about the father’s death
answers.explanation_why: The parent should talk to the child about the effects of the tantrums if the tantrums are impairing family functioning. Not speaking about the father's death may lead to maladaptive behaviors in the family. Children should be allowed to talk about their sadness and loss.

answers.content: Encourage the mother to have a discussion with her daughter about the finality of death
answers.explanation_why: Children can begin to understand the finality of death typically only by 5–7 years of age. At this developmental stage, they start to grasp that death is permanent and that it happens to all living beings. Before this age, children may view death as temporary or reversible. Given her developmental stage, this patient would not be expected to understand the finality of death, so trying to communicate that to her would be inappropriate.

answers.content: Encourage the mother to reinforce positive behaviors and manage the negative behaviors with time-outs
answers.explanation_why: This child lost her father 2 months ago and is in the acute stages of grief. It would not be appropriate to punish her for her grief with time-outs or behavior modifications during this time. The parent should talk to the child about the effects of the tantrums if the tantrums are impairing family functioning.

answers.content: Recommend a referral to a child psychiatrist for the treatment of maladaptive grief reaction
answers.explanation_why: If the child's functioning remains significantly impaired by her father's death, or if her grieving lasts longer than expected, psychological support may be appropriate, but reassurance is the best step at this time.

answers.content: Reassure the mother that her daughter is exhibiting developmentally appropriate bereavement
answers.explanation_why: In this scenario, the mother should be reassured that her child's behaviors are normal and developmentally appropriate. In children aged 2–6 years, normal bereavement behaviors can include shock, numbness, crying, sadness, anger, physical complaints, lack of interest in school, and disobedience. Children may also act out or regress, believe that death is reversible or temporary, or believe that the dead person is still alive and will return — all of which are normal expressions of bereavement at this age. The duration of normal bereavement lasts 6–12 months, but the timing is highly individualized. Children can begin to understand the finality of death typically only by 5–7 years of age, but they should be allowed to talk openly about their sadness and loss.

question_text: A 14-year-old boy with obesity comes to the physician shortly after hospital discharge for a suicide attempt. The patient had attempted to hang himself in a closet with his belt. He has been feeling sad for 6 months, has not been sleeping well, rarely socializes with his friends, and has been doing poorly in school. His mother expresses concern that he spends a lot of time on the computer and his cell phone, usually on social media sites. She is concerned that he may attempt suicide again. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial question by the physician to identify a factor that may precipitate another suicide attempt?
content_preview: A 14-year-old boy with obesity comes to the physician shortly after hospital discharge for a suicide attempt. The patient had attempted to hang himself in a closet with his belt. He has been feeling sad for 6 months, has not been sleeping well, rarely socializes with his friends, and has been doing poorly in school. His mother expresses concern that he spends a lot of time on the computer and his cell phone, usually on social media sites. She is concerned that he may attempt suicide again. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial question by the physician to identify a factor that may precipitate another suicide attempt?
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate question to assess an adolescent’s likelihood of attempting suicide a second time.

answers.content: "Are you being bullied online or at school?"
answers.explanation_why: Intense use of social media in an adolescent with obesity, depression, and a prior suicide attempt raises concern for cyberbullying. Cyberbullying is often an extension of offline bullying behaviors and can lead to depression and suicide. The most appropriate next question to ask this patient is whether he is being bullied at school or online. Asking how the patient feels about his friends, classes, or weight may provide insight, but it is not as important as exploring potential bullying, which is a precipitating factor for a suicide attempt. Assessing sleep is also important, as sleep deprivation is associated with increased suicidal ideation and risk of suicide attempts.

answers.content: "How do you feel about your weight?"
answers.explanation_why: Asking how the patient feels about his weight may provide insight, but it is not as important as exploring a different factor.

answers.content: "Are you concerned about not spending time with your friends?"
answers.explanation_why: Asking how the patient feels about his friends may provide insight, but it is not as important as exploring a different factor.

answers.content: "How do you feel about your classes?"
answers.explanation_why: Asking how the patient feels about his classes may provide insight, but it is not as important as exploring a different factor.

answers.content: "Do you feel like hurting other people?"
answers.explanation_why: Identifying homicidal tendencies is important in any patient who has engaged in deliberate self-harm. The patient must be asked whether he has considered harming anyone else, especially in circumstances that involve bullying, because being bullied increases the risk for aggressive or retaliatory behavior. However, this is not the first question that should be asked of this patient.

question_text: A 15-year-old boy with attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder comes to the physician with his mother for a follow-up evaluation. He has been treated for the past 3 years on a stable dose of methylphenidate. During the evaluation, the patient says that he wishes to discontinue treatment because he does not “like how the medication makes him feel.” His mother does not want him to discontinue the medication. She says that his grades and interactions with his teachers have improved dramatically, and he has been selected for the school’s basketball team. She says, “If he stops the medication, his grades will slip”. Which of the following is the most appropriate subsequent action by the physician?
content_preview: A 15-year-old boy with attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder comes to the physician with his mother for a follow-up evaluation. He has been treated for the past 3 years on a stable dose of methylphenidate. During the evaluation, the patient says that he wishes to discontinue treatment because he does not “like how the medication makes him feel.” His mother does not want him to discontinue the medication. She says that his grades and interactions with his teachers have improved dramatically, and he has been selected for the school’s basketball team. She says, “If he stops the medication, his grades will slip”. Which of the following is the most appropriate subsequent action by the physician?
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate action when an adolescent patient wishes to stop treatment.

answers.content: Speak to the patient in private to find out more about his reasons for wanting to stop treatment
answers.explanation_why: As adolescents mature, they develop the capacity for informed consent and informed refusal at varying rates. Many states have legal exceptions that give adolescents decision-making power regarding certain aspects of their health care (mature minor doctrine). The age at which this doctrine applies varies by state, but generally, adolescents over the age of 14 years are considered capable of making such decisions if they can demonstrate maturity and an understanding of the treatment implications. For adolescents who are legally unable to provide informed consent, their agreement to participate in treatment (informed assent) should be obtained whenever feasible. In this case, in which an adolescent’s wishes conflict with their parents’ preferences, it is important to preserve the therapeutic relationship and address the adolescent’s growing desire for autonomous decisions. The clinician should first have a private discussion with the patient (i.e., without parents present) about the patient's rationale for stopping treatment and their understanding of the risks and benefits of this decision. Subsequently, the physician should facilitate a discussion between the patient and parents and attempt to mediate a consensus. This should be done even when the mature minor doctrine applies, because ideally, the patient would continue to allow his parents to play a significant role in deciding whether or not he continues any form of medical treatment. It is, however, appropriate to temporarily halt treatment that is not urgent or life-sustaining until such a discussion can take place.

answers.content: Speak to the mother in private to evaluate for potential medication misuse or diversion
answers.explanation_why: This action is not necessary at this time because the history does not indicate methylphenidate misuse or diversion by the patient or the parent.

answers.content: Continue the medication because the benefits for the patient outweigh the risks
answers.explanation_why: Although the health care provider's clinical impression and view is important, the final decision of whether to continue the medication is made by either the patient or the parents. Continuing the medication based on the provider's judgment of the risk-benefit balance is not appropriate.

answers.content: Continue the medication to comply with the mother's wishes
answers.explanation_why: Continuing the medication without having further conversations would be inappropriate. Many states have legal exceptions that give adolescents some decision-making power for mental health care. Even if the adolescent is not legally competent to make medical decisions, it is recommended that physicians obtain the adolescent's assent for medical care.

answers.content: Stop the medication because the patient is a mature minor and has decision-making authority
answers.explanation_why: Stopping the medication without having further conversations would be inappropriate. The age at which an adolescent becomes a mature minor varies from state to state. Even if the patient is a mature minor, the clinician should ensure that they are fully aware of any consequences of changing the treatment plan before doing so.

question_text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her friend in a confused, irritable, and disheveled state. Her confusion resolves within an hour, and she recalls being at a party where most of her peers were ingesting random, unidentified pills. She says that she attends parties every weekend, and her parents have been "hassling" her to cut back on the partying. She usually drives herself to and from the parties. She discloses that her grades have recently slipped, and she is less concerned about her future. She also mentions that she has been missing more and more school. Which of the following is the most appropriate question by the physician to screen for a substance use disorder?
content_preview: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her friend in a confused, irritable, and disheveled state. Her confusion resolves within an hour, and she recalls being at a party where most of her peers were ingesting random, unidentified pills. She says that she attends parties every weekend, and her parents have been "hassling" her to cut back on the partying. She usually drives herself to and from the parties. She discloses that her grades have recently slipped, and she is less concerned about her future. She also mentions that she has been missing more and more school. Which of the following is the most appropriate question by the physician to screen for a substance use disorder?
hint: Adolescents who are suspected of substance use disorder can be quickly screened using the CRAFFT questionnaire.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate question to screen an adolescent for a possible substance use disorder.

answers.content: "Why have you been missing so much school?"
answers.explanation_why: Asking about reasons for poor school attendance does not effectively screen for a substance use disorder. Moreover, if a motivational interviewing approach is followed at a later stage of the conversation, a better question to elicit self-reflection would be “How do you feel about your school attendance?”.

answers.content: "How many of your friends get high at parties?"
answers.explanation_why: Understanding drug use among peers can provide insight into social influences, drug use normalization, and access to substances, and help guide interventions for adolescents. However, this question does not effectively screen for a substance use disorder. Moreover, from a motivational interviewing perspective, it is better to focus on the patient's thoughts rather than their friends' behaviors (e.g., “What are your thoughts on drug use at the parties you attend?”).

answers.content: "Do you ever use drugs to relax?"
answers.explanation_why:
The CRAFFT questionnaire involves six questions:

• C: Have you ever driven a car while high or ridden in a car with someone who was high?
• R: Do you ever use alcohol or drugs to relax, feel better about yourself, or fit in?
• A: Do you ever use alcohol or drugs when alone?
• F: Do you ever forget things you did while using alcohol or drugs?
• F: Do your family or friends ever tell you to cut back on your drinking or drug use?
• T: Have you ever gotten into trouble while you were using alcohol or drugs?

Adolescents who answer affirmatively to ≥ 2 of these questions should be assessed further for substance use disorder, and treatment should be recommended accordingly. Even if an adolescent does not answer affirmatively to any of these questions, CRAFFT can be used as an opportunity for further education on drug use.

answers.content: "Do you understand the dangers of drug use?"
answers.explanation_why: This question can sound accusatory and put the patient on the defensive. A different question should be asked to screen for a substance use disorder. Moreover, if a motivational interviewing approach is followed at a later stage of the conversation, a better question to elicit self-reflection would be “What are your thoughts on how drug use might affect one's health?”.

An open-ended question on why the patient uses drugs is important but is not the most appropriate initial question to screen for a substance use disorder, for which a closed-ended question is preferred.

question_text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother because of the sudden onset of repetitive handwashing and facial grimacing for the past week. She reports that he has become increasingly anxious and irritable, refusing to leave the house due to fears of contamination. He has also developed frequent throat clearing and rapid blinking. Three weeks ago, he had a sore throat and fever, which resolved without medical intervention. Medical history is unremarkable, and the patient takes no medications. Family history is unremarkable. He is at the 75th percentile for height and weight. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 102/63 mm Hg. On examination, he is alert and cooperative, but he blinks rapidly and repeatedly asks for permission to wash his hands. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother because of the sudden onset of repetitive handwashing and facial grimacing for the past week. She reports that he has become increasingly anxious and irritable, refusing to leave the house due to fears of contamination. He has also developed frequent throat clearing and rapid blinking. Three weeks ago, he had a sore throat and fever, which resolved without medical intervention. Medical history is unremarkable, and the patient takes no medications. Family history is unremarkable. He is at the 75th percentile for height and weight. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 102/63 mm Hg. On examination, he is alert and cooperative, but he blinks rapidly and repeatedly asks for permission to wash his hands. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient most likely has high antistreptolysin O titers.
learning_objective: Recognize pediatric autoimmune neuropsychiatric disorders associated with streptococcal infections (PANDAS).

answers.content: Pediatric autoimmune neuropsychiatric disorder associated with streptococcal infections
answers.explanation_why: Pediatric autoimmune neuropsychiatric disorder associated with streptococcal infection (PANDAS) is characterized by the sudden onset or exacerbation of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) and motor or vocal tics following Streptococcus pyogenes infection. This child presents with behavioral changes and new-onset tics, appearing 3 weeks after acute tonsillitis, which is consistent with PANDAS. Diagnosis is clinical and requires a recent history of GAS infection combined with abrupt systemic onset. Management includes eradication of the underlying group A streptococcus infection, as well as cognitive behavioral therapy and pharmacotherapy for OCD and tic disorder.

Transient tic disorder involves motor and/or vocal tics lasting less than one year, often without a clear precipitant. Although the patient has tics, the presence of acute-onset obsessive-compulsive behaviors and a history of recent tonsillitis make this diagnosis less likely.

Sydenham chorea is characterized by involuntary, rapid, irregular movements of the limbs, neck, head, and/or face. While this patient presents with irregular movements of the face (facial grimacing, rapid blinking, throat clearing), these features are more consistent with tics. In addition, this patient also has obsessive-compulsive symptoms (frequent handwashing) that are not sufficiently explained by Sydenham chorea. Moreover, Sydenham chorea typically manifests 1–8 months after untreated streptococcal pharyngitis, whereas this patient's symptoms appeared three weeks after infection.

Tourette syndrome manifests with both motor and vocal tics before age 18 and persists for more than one year. Although this patient has both types of tics, Tourette syndrome typically develops gradually and is not associated with a sudden, dramatic onset or a clear preceding infection. The abrupt appearance of obsessive-compulsive symptoms and the temporal association with a recent streptococcal infection make Tourette syndrome less likely.

Pediatric obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is marked by persistent, intrusive obsessions and compulsions but usually develops insidiously over months or years. While this patient’s compulsive handwashing and contamination fears are consistent with OCD, acute symptom onset in combination with new motor and vocal tics and recent history of acute tonsillitis makes a different diagnosis more likely.

question_text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient clinic by his mother because of involuntary grimacing and throat clearing for the past 13 months. He also frequently experiences episodes of sudden, brief shoulder jerks several times per day. These movements increase when he is anxious and are sometimes accompanied by vocal outbursts, such as grunting. He is performing well academically but has become self-conscious around classmates. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. His maternal uncle has attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. On physical examination, the patient repeatedly clears his throat, grimaces, and shrugs his shoulders. The rest of the examination shows no abnormalities. Brain MRI shows reduced caudate nuclei volume. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy for this patient?
content_preview: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient clinic by his mother because of involuntary grimacing and throat clearing for the past 13 months. He also frequently experiences episodes of sudden, brief shoulder jerks several times per day. These movements increase when he is anxious and are sometimes accompanied by vocal outbursts, such as grunting. He is performing well academically but has become self-conscious around classmates. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. His maternal uncle has attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. On physical examination, the patient repeatedly clears his throat, grimaces, and shrugs his shoulders. The rest of the examination shows no abnormalities. Brain MRI shows reduced caudate nuclei volume. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy for this patient?
hint: This patient presents with involuntary vocal and motor tics and a normal physical examination. In conjunction with the MRI findings, these features suggest Tourette syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Tourette syndrome, and choose the best initial therapy

answers.explanation_why: Botulinum toxin injections partially paralyze the muscles and may be used for controlling focal motor tics or vocal tics in adults and adolescents. This patient presents with generalized motor tics for which another initial therapy is more appropriate.

Methylphenidate is used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, which is often concurrent with Tourette syndrome. However, methylphenidate does not treat tics and occasionally worsens them. A different therapy that treats tics is indicated in this patient.

Deep brain stimulation is reserved for severe, refractory Tourette syndrome that has not responded to other treatment modalities and is causing significant functional impairment. This approach is not appropriate as initial therapy, especially in children, because it is invasive, and there is limited long-term data on its safety and efficacy in pediatric populations.

Comprehensive behavioral intervention for tics (CBIT) that includes habit reversal therapy is the first-line treatment for children with Tourette syndrome. This approach involves increasing the patient's awareness of premonitory urges and training them to perform voluntary, competing responses when they feel tics coming on. Early behavioral intervention can reduce tic frequency and social consequences, and is preferred due to its safety and efficacy. Pharmacotherapy (e.g., guanfacine, haloperidol, tetrabenazine) is reserved for severe tics that cause functional impairment and/or when behavioral interventions fail.

Tourette syndrome is characterized by both motor and vocal tics persisting for over a year, often exacerbated by stress or anxiety. MRI typically shows reduced caudate nucleus volume, reflecting dysfunction in cortico-striatal-thalamo-cortical circuits.

Haloperidol may be used in the treatment of Tourette syndrome, but it is not the first-line therapy because of the risk of extrapyramidal adverse effects, sedation, and cognitive dulling. Pharmacotherapy is reserved for patients with severe tics that cause functional impairment and/or those who do not respond to initial therapy. This patient has mild-to-moderate symptoms and preserved functioning, so another initial therapy is more appropriate.
